**Budapest** ^[\[a\]](#cite_note-11)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [most populous city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_of_Hungary "List of cities and towns of Hungary") of [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary"). It is the [tenth-largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") by population within city limits and the [second largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_on_Danube_river "List of cities and towns on Danube river") on the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") river.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-TIME2-12)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^ The city has an estimated population of 1,752,286 over a land area of about 525 square kilometres (203 square miles).^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^ Budapest, which is both a [city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_of_Hungary "List of cities and towns of Hungary") and [municipality](/wiki/Counties_of_Hungary "Counties of Hungary"), forms the centre of the [Budapest metropolitan area](/wiki/Budapest_metropolitan_area "Budapest metropolitan area"), which has an area of 7,626 square kilometres (2,944 square miles) and a population of 3,303,786. It is a [primate city](/wiki/Primate_city "Primate city"), constituting 33% of the population of Hungary.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^{#cite_ref-17}

The [history of Budapest](/wiki/History_of_Budapest "History of Budapest") began when an early [Celtic](/wiki/Celts "Celts") settlement transformed into the [Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") town of [Aquincum](/wiki/Aquincum "Aquincum"),^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Aqua-18)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^ the capital of [Lower Pannonia](/wiki/Pannonia_Inferior "Pannonia Inferior").^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Aqua-18)^ The [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarian_people "Hungarian people") arrived in the territory in the late 9th century,^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Travel-20)^ but the area was pillaged by the [Mongols](/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Europe "Mongol invasion of Europe") in 1241--42.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-Eleventh-21)^ Re-established [Buda](/wiki/Buda "Buda") became one of the centres of [Renaissance humanist](/wiki/Renaissance_humanism "Renaissance humanism") culture by the 15th century.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^ The [Battle of Mohács](/wiki/Battle_of_Moh%C3%A1cs "Battle of Mohács"), in 1526, was followed by nearly 150 years of [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") rule.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^ After the [reconquest of Buda](/wiki/Siege_of_Buda_(1686) "Siege of Buda (1686)") in 1686, the region entered a new age of prosperity, with Pest-Buda becoming a global city after the unification of Buda, [Óbuda](/wiki/%C3%93buda "Óbuda") and [Pest](/wiki/Pest,_Hungary "Pest, Hungary") on 17 November 1873, with the name 'Budapest' given to the new capital.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^ Budapest also became the co-capital of the [Austro-Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary"),^[\[26\]](#cite_note-27)^ a [great power](/wiki/Great_power "Great power") that dissolved in 1918, following [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). The city was the focal point of the [Hungarian Revolution of 1848](/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848 "Hungarian Revolution of 1848") and the [Battle of Budapest](/wiki/Battle_of_Budapest "Battle of Budapest") in 1945, as well as the [Hungarian Revolution of 1956](/wiki/1956_Hungarian_Revolution "1956 Hungarian Revolution").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^^[\[28\]](#cite_note-wilson-29)^{#cite_ref-wilson_29-0}

Budapest is a global city with strengths in commerce, finance, media, art, fashion, research, technology, education, and entertainment.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-auto1-31)^ Hungary's [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre"), Budapest is also the headquarters of the [European Institute of Innovation and Technology](/wiki/European_Institute_of_Innovation_and_Technology "European Institute of Innovation and Technology"),^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^ the [European Police College](/wiki/European_Police_College "European Police College")^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ and the first foreign office of the [China Investment Promotion Agency](/wiki/China_Investment_Promotion_Agency "China Investment Promotion Agency").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)^ [Over 40 colleges and universities](/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Hungary "List of universities in Hungary") are located in Budapest, including [Eötvös Loránd University](/wiki/E%C3%B6tv%C3%B6s_Lor%C3%A1nd_University "Eötvös Loránd University"), [Corvinus University](/wiki/Corvinus_University "Corvinus University"), [Semmelweis University](/wiki/Semmelweis_University "Semmelweis University"), [University of Veterinary Medicine Budapest](/wiki/University_of_Veterinary_Medicine_Budapest "University of Veterinary Medicine Budapest") and the [Budapest University of Technology and Economics](/wiki/Budapest_University_of_Technology_and_Economics "Budapest University of Technology and Economics").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^ Opened in 1896,^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ the city's subway system, the [Budapest Metro](/wiki/Budapest_Metro "Budapest Metro"), serves 1.27 million, while the [Budapest Tram Network](/wiki/Trams_in_Budapest "Trams in Budapest") serves 1.08 million passengers daily.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-BKV-report-38)^{#cite_ref-BKV-report_38-0}

The central area of Budapest along the [Danube River](/wiki/Danube "Danube") is classified as a [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") and has several notable monuments of [classical architecture](/wiki/Classical_architecture "Classical architecture"), including the [Hungarian Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building") and the [Buda Castle](/wiki/Buda_Castle "Buda Castle").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^ The city also has around [80 geothermal springs](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Medicinal_Bath "Széchenyi Medicinal Bath"),^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^ the largest thermal water cave system,^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ second largest [synagogue](/wiki/Doh%C3%A1ny_Street_Synagogue "Dohány Street Synagogue"), and third largest [Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building") building in the world.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^ Budapest [attracts](/wiki/Tourism_in_Hungary "Tourism in Hungary") around 12 million international tourists per year, making it a highly popular destination in Europe.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-euromonitor-43)^{#cite_ref-euromonitor_43-0}  

Etymology and pronunciation {#Etymology_and_pronunciation}
----------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology and pronunciation")\]

The previously separate cities of Buda, Óbuda, and Pest were officially unified in 1873^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^ and given the new name *Budapest* . Before this, the towns together had sometimes been referred to colloquially as "Pest-Buda".^[\[44\]](#cite_note-Jones_2017-45)^^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ *Pest* is often used *[pars pro toto](/wiki/Pars_pro_toto "Pars pro toto")* for the entire city in contemporary colloquial Hungarian,^[\[44\]](#cite_note-Jones_2017-45)^ although it is also used to refer to all parts of the city east of the Danube. Conversely, *Buda* colloquially means all districts to the Danube's west---including the former Óbuda. The Danube islands---including [Csepel](/wiki/Csepel "Csepel"), the city's XXI. district---are part of neither Buda nor Pest.{#cite_ref-Jones_2017_45-1}

All varieties of English pronounce the *-s-* as in the English word *pest* . The *-u* in *Buda-* is pronounced either /u/ like *food* (as in [US](/wiki/American_English "American English"): [/ˈbuːdəpɛst/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^) or /ju/ like *cue* (as in [UK](/wiki/British_English "British English"): [/ˌb(j)uːdəˈpɛst, ˌbʊd-, ˈb(j)uːdəpɛst, ˈbʊd-/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")). In Hungarian, the *-s-* is pronounced /ʃ/ as in *wash* ; in IPA:
Hungarian: [\[ˈbudɒpɛʃt\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Hungarian "Help:IPA/Hungarian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d9/Hu-Budapest.ogg/Hu-Budapest.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Hu-Budapest.ogg "File:Hu-Budapest.ogg")^.{#ooui-php-3}

The origins of the names "Buda" and "Pest" are obscure. Buda was

* probably the name of the first constable of the fortress built on the Castle Hill in the 11th century^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^{#cite_ref-48}
* or a derivative of *Bod* or *Bud* , a personal name of [Turkic](/wiki/Turkic_languages "Turkic languages") origin, meaning 'twig'.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}
* or a [Slavic](/wiki/Slavic_languages "Slavic languages") personal name, *Buda* , the short form of *Budimír* , *Budivoj* .^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^{#cite_ref-50}

Linguistically, however, a German origin through the Slavic derivative вода (*voda* , water) is not possible, and there is no certainty that a Turkic word really comes from the word *buta* \~ *buda* 'branch, twig'.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}

According to a legend recorded in chronicles from the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), "Buda" comes from the name of its founder, [Bleda](/wiki/Bleda "Bleda"), brother of Hunnic ruler [Attila](/wiki/Attila "Attila").
> [Attila](/wiki/Attila "Attila") went in the city of Sicambria in Pannonia, where he killed [Buda](/wiki/Bleda "Bleda"), his brother, and he threw his corpse into the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube"). For while [Attila](/wiki/Attila "Attila") was in the west, his brother crossed the boundaries in his reign, because he named Sicambria after his own name Buda's Castle. And though King [Attila](/wiki/Attila "Attila") forbade the Huns and the other peoples to call that city Buda's Castle, but he called it Attila's Capital, the Germans who were terrified by the prohibition named the city as Eccylburg, which means Attila Castle, however, the Hungarians did not care about the ban and call it Óbuda \[Old Buda\] and call it to this day.  
> --- [Mark of Kalt](/wiki/Mark_of_Kalt "Mark of Kalt"): *[Chronicon Pictum](/wiki/Chronicon_Pictum "Chronicon Pictum")* ^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^
> The [Scythians](/wiki/Scythians "Scythians") are certainly an ancient people and the strength of [Scythia](/wiki/Scythia "Scythia") lies in the east, as we said above. And the first king of [Scythia](/wiki/Scythia "Scythia") was Magog, son of Japhet, and his people were called Magyars \[Hungarians\] after their King Magog, from whose royal line the most renowned and mighty King [Attila](/wiki/Attila "Attila") descended, who, in the 451st year of Our Lord's birth, coming down from [Scythia](/wiki/Scythia "Scythia"), entered Pannonia with a mighty force and, putting the Romans to flight, took the realm and made a royal residence for himself beside the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") above the hot springs, and he ordered all the old buildings that he found there to be restored and he built them in a circular and very strong wall that in the Hungarian language is now called Budavár \[Buda Castle\] and by the Germans Etzelburg \[Attila Castle\]  
> --- [Anonymus](/wiki/Anonymus_(notary_of_B%C3%A9la_III) "Anonymus (notary of Béla III)"): *[Gesta Hungarorum](/wiki/Gesta_Hungarorum "Gesta Hungarorum")* ^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^

There are several theories about Pest. One^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^ states that the name derives from [Roman times](/wiki/Pannonia_(Roman_province) "Pannonia (Roman province)"), since there was a local fortress ([Contra-Aquincum](/wiki/Contra-Aquincum "Contra-Aquincum")) called by [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy") "Pession" ("Πέσσιον", iii.7.§ 2).^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^ Another has it that Pest originates in the Slavic word for cave, *пещера* , or *peštera* . A third cites *пещ* , or *pešt* , referencing a cave where fires burned or a limekiln.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Budapest](/wiki/History_of_Budapest "History of Budapest")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Budapest](/wiki/Timeline_of_Budapest "Timeline of Budapest").  

### Early history {#Early_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Early history")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Nuremberg_chronicles_-_BVJA.png/450px-Nuremberg_chronicles_-_BVJA.png)](/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_-_BVJA.png) [Buda](/wiki/Buda "Buda") during the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), woodcut from the [Nuremberg Chronicle](/wiki/Nuremberg_Chronicle "Nuremberg Chronicle") (1493)

The first settlement on the territory of Budapest was built by [Celts](/wiki/Celts "Celts")^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Aqua-18)^ before 1 AD. It was later occupied by the [Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome"). The Roman settlement -- [Aquincum](/wiki/Aquincum "Aquincum") -- became the main city of [Pannonia Inferior](/wiki/Pannonia_(Roman_province) "Pannonia (Roman province)") in 106 AD.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Aqua-18)^ At first it was a military settlement, and gradually the city rose around it, making it the focal point of the city's commercial life. Today this area corresponds to the Óbuda district within Budapest.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^ The Romans constructed roads, [amphitheaters](/wiki/Amphitheater "Amphitheater"), [baths](/wiki/Public_bathing "Public bathing") and houses with heated floors in this fortified military camp.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-Frank-58)^ The Roman city of Aquincum is the best-conserved of the Roman sites in [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary"). The archaeological site was turned into a museum with indoor and open-air sections.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^ Meanwhile, settlement in the area east of the Danube, which was not part of the Roman Empire, remained Germanic and Sarmatian in character.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

[The Magyar](/wiki/Hungarian_people "Hungarian people") tribes led by [Árpád](/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1d "Árpád"), forced out of their original homeland north of [Bulgaria](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire") by [Tsar Simeon](/wiki/Simeon_I_of_Bulgaria "Simeon I of Bulgaria") after the [Battle of Southern Buh](/wiki/Battle_of_Southern_Buh "Battle of Southern Buh"), settled in the territory at the end of the 9th century displacing the founding Bulgarian settlers of the towns of Buda and Pest,^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Travel-20)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^ and a century later officially founded the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary").^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Travel-20)^ Research places the probable residence of the [Árpáds](/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1ds "Árpáds") as an early place of central power near what became Budapest.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^ The [Tatar](/wiki/Tatars "Tatars") invasion in the 13th century quickly proved it is difficult to defend a plain.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Travel-20)^ King [Béla IV of Hungary](/wiki/B%C3%A9la_IV_of_Hungary "Béla IV of Hungary"), therefore, ordered the construction of reinforced stone walls around the towns^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Travel-20)^ and set his own royal palace on the top of the protecting hills of Buda. In 1361 it became the capital of Hungary.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-Eleventh-21)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^{#cite_ref-Encarta_15-3}

The cultural role of Buda was particularly significant during the reign of [King Matthias Corvinus](/wiki/Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary "Matthias Corvinus of Hungary"). The [Italian Renaissance](/wiki/Italian_Renaissance "Italian Renaissance") had a great influence on the city. His library, the [Bibliotheca Corviniana](/wiki/Bibliotheca_Corviniana "Bibliotheca Corviniana"), was Europe's greatest collection of historical chronicles and philosophic and scientific works in the 15th century, and second in size only to the [Vatican Library](/wiki/Vatican_Library "Vatican Library").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^ After the foundation of the first Hungarian university in [Pécs](/wiki/P%C3%A9cs "Pécs") in 1367 ([University of Pécs](/wiki/University_of_P%C3%A9cs "University of Pécs")), the second one was established in Óbuda in 1395 ([University of Óbuda](/wiki/University_of_%C3%93buda "University of Óbuda")).^[\[62\]](#cite_note-Sugar-63)^ The first Hungarian book was printed in Buda in 1473.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-64)^ Buda had about 5,000 inhabitants around the year 1500.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Peter_F._Sugar_page_88-65)^{#cite_ref-Peter_F._Sugar_page_88_65-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Reprise_Buda_1686.jpg/220px-Reprise_Buda_1686.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reprise_Buda_1686.jpg) *Retaking of Buda from the Ottoman Empire* , painted by [Frans Geffels](/wiki/Frans_Geffels "Frans Geffels") in 1686

The [Ottomans](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") conquered Buda in 1526, as well as in 1529, and finally occupied it in 1541.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-66)^ The [Ottoman Rule](/wiki/Ottoman_Hungary "Ottoman Hungary") lasted for more than 150 years.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^ The Ottoman [Turks](/wiki/Turkish_people "Turkish people") constructed many prominent bathing facilities within the city.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-Travel-20)^ Some of the baths that the Turks erected during their rule are still in use 500 years later, including [Rudas Baths](/wiki/Rudas_Baths "Rudas Baths") and [Király Baths](/wiki/Kir%C3%A1ly_Baths "Király Baths"). By 1547 the number of Christians was down to about a thousand, and by 1647 it had fallen to only about seventy.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Peter_F._Sugar_page_88-65)^ The unoccupied western part of the country became part of the [Habsburg monarchy](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy") as [Royal Hungary](/wiki/Royal_Hungary "Royal Hungary").{#cite_ref-Peter_F._Sugar_page_88_65-1}

In 1686, two years after the unsuccessful [siege of Buda](/wiki/Siege_of_Buda_(1684) "Siege of Buda (1684)"), a renewed campaign was started to enter Buda. This time, the [Holy League](/wiki/Holy_League_(1684) "Holy League (1684)")'s army was twice as large, containing over 74,000 men, including [German](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire "Holy Roman Empire"), [Croat](/wiki/Croat "Croat"), [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people"), Hungarian, English, Spanish, [Czech](/wiki/Czechs "Czechs"), Italian, French, [Burgundian](/wiki/Burgundians "Burgundians"), [Danish](/wiki/Danes "Danes") and Swedish soldiers, along with other Europeans as volunteers, [artillerymen](/wiki/Artillery "Artillery"), and officers. The Christian forces seized Buda, and in the next few years, all of the former Hungarian lands, except areas near Temesvár ([Timișoara](/wiki/Timi%C8%99oara "Timișoara")), were taken from the Turks. In the 1699 [Treaty of Karlowitz](/wiki/Treaty_of_Karlowitz "Treaty of Karlowitz"), these territorial changes were officially recognized as the end of the rule of the Turks, and in 1718 the entire [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary") was removed from [Ottoman rule](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire").

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Contemporary history after Unification")\]  
See also: [Hungary during World War II](/wiki/Hungary_during_World_War_II "Hungary during World War II")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Budapest%2C_M1_metr%C3%B3_%28kisf%C3%B6ldalatti%29%2C_Andr%C3%A1ssy_%C3%BAt.png/220px-Budapest%2C_M1_metr%C3%B3_%28kisf%C3%B6ldalatti%29%2C_Andr%C3%A1ssy_%C3%BAt.png)](/wiki/File:Budapest,_M1_metr%C3%B3_(kisf%C3%B6ldalatti),_Andr%C3%A1ssy_%C3%BAt.png) [Millennium Underground](/wiki/Line_1_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 1 (Budapest Metro)") (1894--1896), the second oldest metro in the world (after the [Metropolitan line](/wiki/Metropolitan_line "Metropolitan line")^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ of the [London Underground](/wiki/London_Underground "London Underground")) [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Jakobey_Buda_ostroma_2.jpg/220px-Jakobey_Buda_ostroma_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jakobey_Buda_ostroma_2.jpg) The [Hungarian revolutionary army](/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848 "Hungarian Revolution of 1848") liberates the Buda castle in May 1849.

The 19th century was dominated by the Hungarian struggle for independence^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^ and modernisation. The national insurrection against the [Habsburgs](/wiki/Habsburgs "Habsburgs") began in the Hungarian capital [in 1848](/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848 "Hungarian Revolution of 1848") and was defeated one and a half years later, with the help of the Russian Empire. 1867 was the year of [Reconciliation](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Compromise_of_1867 "Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867") that brought about the birth of [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary"). This made Budapest the twin capital of a dual monarchy. It was this compromise which opened the second great phase of development in the [history of Budapest](/wiki/History_of_Budapest "History of Budapest"), lasting until [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). In 1849 the [Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge") linking Buda with Pest was opened as the first permanent bridge across the Danube^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^ and in 1873 Buda and Pest were officially merged with the third part, Óbuda (Old Buda), thus creating the new metropolis of Budapest. The dynamic Pest grew into the country's administrative, political, economic, trade and cultural hub. Ethnic [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarians "Hungarians") overtook [Germans](/wiki/Danube_Swabians "Danube Swabians") in the second half of the 19th century due to mass migration from the overpopulated rural [Transdanubia](/wiki/Transdanubia "Transdanubia") and [Great Hungarian Plain](/wiki/Great_Hungarian_Plain "Great Hungarian Plain"). Between 1851 and 1910 the proportion of Hungarians increased from 35.6% to 85.9%, Hungarian became the dominant language, and German was crowded out. The proportion of Jews peaked in 1900 with 23.6%.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-68)^^[\[68\]](#cite_note-69)^^[\[69\]](#cite_note-Budapest_1946_p._12-70)^ Due to the prosperity and the large Jewish community of the city at the start of the 20th century, Budapest was often called the "Jewish Mecca"^[\[20\]](#cite_note-Eleventh-21)^ or "Judapest".^[\[70\]](#cite_note-71)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-72)^ Budapest also became an important center for the [Aromanian diaspora](/wiki/Aromanian_diaspora "Aromanian diaspora") during the 19th century.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ In 1918, Austria-Hungary lost the war and collapsed; Hungary declared itself an independent republic ([Republic of Hungary](/wiki/Republic_of_Hungary "Republic of Hungary")). In 1920 the [Treaty of Trianon](/wiki/Treaty_of_Trianon "Treaty of Trianon") partitioned the country, and as a result, Hungary lost over two-thirds of its territory, and about two-thirds of its inhabitants, including 3.3 million out of 15 million ethnic Hungarians.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-Macartney37-74)^^[\[74\]](#cite_note-75)^{#cite_ref-75}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/D%C3%B6rre_The_Budapest_Opera_House_c._1890.jpg/220px-D%C3%B6rre_The_Budapest_Opera_House_c._1890.jpg)](/wiki/File:D%C3%B6rre_The_Budapest_Opera_House_c._1890.jpg) The [Hungarian State Opera House](/wiki/Hungarian_State_Opera_House "Hungarian State Opera House"), built in the time of [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Ville_de_Budapest_1911.jpg/220px-Ville_de_Budapest_1911.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ville_de_Budapest_1911.jpg) Bond of the City of Budapest, issued 1 May 1911 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg/220px-Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg) The [Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge") was destroyed during the [Siege of Budapest](/wiki/Siege_of_Budapest "Siege of Budapest"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Szent_Istv%C3%A1n_k%C3%B6r%C3%BAt_a_Falk_Miksa_%28N%C3%A9phadsereg%29_utca_fel%C5%91l_a_Honv%C3%A9d_utca_fel%C3%A9_n%C3%A9zve._A_szovjet_csapatok_ideiglenes_kivonul%C3%A1sa_1956._okt%C3%B3ber_31-%C3%A9n._Fortepan_24787.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg)](/wiki/File:Szent_Istv%C3%A1n_k%C3%B6r%C3%BAt_a_Falk_Miksa_(N%C3%A9phadsereg)_utca_fel%C5%91l_a_Honv%C3%A9d_utca_fel%C3%A9_n%C3%A9zve._A_szovjet_csapatok_ideiglenes_kivonul%C3%A1sa_1956._okt%C3%B3ber_31-%C3%A9n._Fortepan_24787.jpg) Soviet tanks in Budapest (1956)

In 1944, a year before the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Budapest was partly destroyed by [British](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force") and [American](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces") air raids (first attack 4 April 1944^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^). From 24 December 1944 to 13 February 1945, the city was besieged during the [Battle of Budapest](/wiki/Battle_of_Budapest "Battle of Budapest"). Budapest sustained major damage caused by the attacking Soviet and Romanian troops and the defending [German](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht") and Hungarian troops. More than 38,000 civilians died during the conflict. [All bridges](/wiki/Bridges_of_Budapest "Bridges of Budapest") were destroyed by the Germans. The stone lions that have decorated the Chain Bridge since 1852 survived the devastation of the war.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-chbridge-79)^{#cite_ref-chbridge_79-0}

Between 20% and 40% of Greater Budapest's 250,000 Jewish inhabitants died through [Nazi](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism") and [Arrow Cross Party](/wiki/Arrow_Cross_Party "Arrow Cross Party"), during the [German occupation of Hungary](/wiki/Operation_Panzerfaust "Operation Panzerfaust"), from 1944 to early 1945.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-80)^{#cite_ref-80}

Swiss diplomat [Carl Lutz](/wiki/Carl_Lutz "Carl Lutz") rescued tens of thousands of Jews by issuing Swiss protection papers and designating numerous buildings, including the now famous Glass House (Üvegház) at Vadász Street 29, to be Swiss protected territory. About 3,000 Hungarian Jews found refuge at the Glass House and in a neighboring building. Swedish diplomat [Raoul Wallenberg](/wiki/Raoul_Wallenberg "Raoul Wallenberg") saved the lives of tens of thousands of Jews in Budapest by giving them Swedish protection papers and taking them under his consular protection.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-81)^ Wallenberg was abducted by the Russians on 17 January 1945 and never regained freedom. [Giorgio Perlasca](/wiki/Giorgio_Perlasca "Giorgio Perlasca"), an Italian citizen, saved thousands of Hungarian Jews posing as a Spanish diplomat.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-timeisrael-82)^^[\[82\]](#cite_note-ushm-83)^ Some other diplomats also abandoned diplomatic protocol and rescued Jews. There are two monuments for Wallenberg, one for Carl Lutz and one for Giorgio Perlasca in Budapest.{#cite_ref-ushm_83-0}

Following the capture of Hungary from [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") by the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army"), [Soviet military occupation](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Hungary "Soviet occupation of Hungary") ensued, which ended only in 1991. The Soviets exerted significant influence on Hungarian political affairs. In 1949, Hungary was declared a [communist](/wiki/Communism "Communism") People's Republic ([People's Republic of Hungary](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Hungary "People's Republic of Hungary")). The new Communist government considered the buildings like the [Buda Castle](/wiki/Buda_Castle "Buda Castle") symbols of the former regime, and during the 1950s the palace was gutted and all the interiors were destroyed (also see [Stalin era](/wiki/Stalin_era "Stalin era")). On 23 October 1956 citizens held a large peaceful demonstration in Budapest demanding democratic reform. The demonstrators went to the Budapest radio station and demanded to publish their demands. The regime ordered troops to shoot into the crowd. Hungarian soldiers gave rifles to the demonstrators who were now able to capture the building. This initiated the [Hungarian Revolution of 1956](/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956 "Hungarian Revolution of 1956"). The demonstrators demanded to appoint [Imre Nagy](/wiki/Imre_Nagy "Imre Nagy") to be [Prime Minister of Hungary](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Hungary "Prime Minister of Hungary"). To their surprise, the central committee of the "[Hungarian Working People's Party](/wiki/Hungarian_Working_People%27s_Party "Hungarian Working People's Party")" did so that same evening. This uprising was an anti-Soviet revolt that lasted from 23 October until 11 November. After Nagy had declared that Hungary was to leave the [Warsaw Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact "Warsaw Pact") and become neutral, Soviet tanks and troops entered the country to crush the revolt. Fighting continued until mid November, leaving more than 3000 dead. A monument was erected at the fiftieth anniversary of the revolt in 2006, at the edge of the [City Park](/wiki/City_Park_(Budapest) "City Park (Budapest)"). Its shape is a wedge with a 56 angle degree made in rusted iron that gradually becomes shiny, ending in an intersection to symbolize Hungarian forces that temporarily eradicated the Communist leadership.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}

From the 1960s to the late 1980s Hungary was often satirically referred to as "[the happiest barrack](/wiki/Goulash_Communism "Goulash Communism")" within the [Eastern bloc](/wiki/Eastern_bloc "Eastern bloc"), and much of the wartime damage to the city was finally repaired. Work on [Erzsébet Bridge](/wiki/Erzs%C3%A9bet_Bridge "Erzsébet Bridge"), the last to be rebuilt, was finished in 1964. In the early 1970s, [Budapest Metro](/wiki/Budapest_Metro "Budapest Metro")'s east--west [M2 line](/wiki/Line_2_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 2 (Budapest Metro)") was first opened, followed by the [M3 line](/wiki/Line_3_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 3 (Budapest Metro)") in 1976. In 1987, Buda Castle and the banks of the Danube were included in the [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") list of [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites "World Heritage Sites"). [Andrássy Avenue](/wiki/Andr%C3%A1ssy_Avenue "Andrássy Avenue") (including the [Millennium Underground Railway](/wiki/Millennium_Underground_Railway "Millennium Underground Railway"), [Hősök tere](/wiki/H%C5%91s%C3%B6k_tere "Hősök tere"), and [Városliget](/wiki/V%C3%A1rosliget "Városliget")) was added to the UNESCO list in 2002. In the 1980s, the city's population reached 2.1 million. In recent times a significant decrease in population occurred mainly due to a massive movement to the neighbouring agglomeration in [Pest county](/wiki/Pest_county "Pest county"), i.e., suburbanisation.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}

In the last decades of the 20th century the political changes of 1989--90 ([Fall of the Iron Curtain](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Iron_Curtain "Fall of the Iron Curtain")) concealed changes in civil society and along the streets of Budapest. The monuments of the dictatorship were removed from public places, into [Memento Park](/wiki/Memento_Park "Memento Park"). In the first 20 years of the new democracy, the development of the city was managed by its mayor, [Gábor Demszky](/wiki/G%C3%A1bor_Demszky "Gábor Demszky").^[\[85\]](#cite_note-86)^{#cite_ref-86}

In October 2019, opposition candidate [Gergely Karácsony](/wiki/Gergely_Kar%C3%A1csony "Gergely Karácsony") won the Budapest mayoral [election](/wiki/2019_Budapest_mayoral_election "2019 Budapest mayoral election"), meaning the first electoral blow for Hungary's nationalist prime minister [Viktor Orbán](/wiki/Viktor_Orb%C3%A1n "Viktor Orbán") since coming to power in 2010.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-87)^{#cite_ref-87}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Topography {#Topography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Topography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Budapest_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-07-28.jpg/220px-Budapest_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-07-28.jpg)](/wiki/File:Budapest_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-07-28.jpg) [Satellite imagery](/wiki/Satellite_imagery "Satellite imagery") of Budapest

Budapest, strategically placed at the centre of the [Pannonian Basin](/wiki/Pannonian_Basin "Pannonian Basin"), lies on an ancient route linking the hills of Transdanubia with the Great Plain. By road it is 216 kilometres (134 mi) south-east of [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), 545 kilometres (339 mi) south of [Warsaw](/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw"), 1,565 kilometres (972 mi) south-west of Moscow, 1,122 kilometres (697 mi) north of [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), 1,235 kilometres (767 mi) north-east of [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"), 788 kilometres (490 mi) north-east of [Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan"), 443 kilometres (275 mi) south-east of [Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague"), 343 kilometres (213 mi) north-east of [Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb"), 748 kilometres (465 mi) north-east of [Split](/wiki/Split,_Croatia "Split, Croatia") and 1,329 kilometres (826 mi) north-west of [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul").^[\[87\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}

The 525 square kilometres (203 sq mi) area of Budapest lies in [Central Hungary](/wiki/Central_Hungary "Central Hungary"), surrounded by settlements of the agglomeration in Pest county. The capital extends 25 and 29 km (16 and 18 mi) in the north--south, east--west direction respectively. The Danube enters the city from the north; later it encircles two islands, [Óbuda Island](/wiki/%C3%93buda_Island "Óbuda Island") and [Margaret Island](/wiki/Margaret_Island "Margaret Island").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^ The third island [Csepel Island](/wiki/Csepel_Island "Csepel Island") is the largest of the Budapest Danube islands, however only its northernmost tip is within city limits. The river that separates the two parts of the city is 230 m (755 ft) wide at its narrowest point in Budapest. Pest lies on the flat terrain of the Great Plain while Buda is rather hilly.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Encarta-15)^{#cite_ref-Encarta_15-8}

The wide Danube was always fordable at this point because of a small number of islands in the middle of the river. The city has marked topographical contrasts: Buda is built on the higher river terraces and hills of the western side, while the considerably larger Pest spreads out on a flat and featureless sand plain on the river's opposite bank.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-89)^ Pest's terrain rises with a slight eastward gradient, so the easternmost parts of the city lie at the same altitude as Buda's smallest hills, notably [Gellért Hill](/wiki/Gell%C3%A9rt_Hill "Gellért Hill") and Castle Hill.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-budapest.com-90)^{#cite_ref-budapest.com_90-0}

The Buda hills consist mainly of limestone and dolomite, the water created [speleothems](/wiki/Speleothem "Speleothem"), the most famous ones being the Pálvölgyi cave (total length 7,200 m or 23,600 ft) and the Szemlőhegyi cave (total length 2,200 m or 7,200 ft). The hills were formed in the Triassic Period. The highest point of the hills and of Budapest is [János Hill](/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_Hill "János Hill"), at 527 metres (1,729 feet) [above sea level](/wiki/Above_sea_level "Above sea level"). The lowest point is the line of the Danube which is 96 metres (315 feet) above sea level. Budapest is also rich in green areas. Of the 525 square kilometres (203 square miles) occupied by the city, 83 square kilometres (32 square miles) is green area, park and forest.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-91)^ The forests of [Buda hills](/wiki/Buda_hills "Buda hills") are environmentally protected.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-92)^{#cite_ref-92}

The city's importance in terms of traffic is very central, because many major [European roads](/wiki/European_roads "European roads") and [European railway](/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Europe "Rail transport in Europe") lines lead to Budapest.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-budapest.com-90)^ The Danube was and is still an important water-way and this region in the centre of the Carpathian Basin lies at the cross-roads of [trade routes](/wiki/Trade_route "Trade route").^[\[92\]](#cite_note-budpocketguide.com-93)^ Budapest is one of only three capital cities in the world which has [thermal springs](/wiki/Hot_spring "Hot spring") (the others being [Reykjavík](/wiki/Reykjav%C3%ADk "Reykjavík") in [Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland") and [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia") in [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria")). Some 125 springs produce 70 million litres (18 million US gallons) of thermal water a day, with temperatures ranging up to 58 °C. Some of these waters have been claimed to have medicinal effects due to their high mineral contents.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-budapest.com-90)^{#cite_ref-budapest.com_90-2}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Climate")\]  
Main article: [Climate of Budapest](/wiki/Climate_of_Budapest "Climate of Budapest")

Budapest has a transitional climate between a [humid temperate climate](/wiki/Humid_temperate_climate "Humid temperate climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *[Cfa](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate")* , [Trewartha](/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification "Trewartha climate classification"): *[Doak](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate")* ), and a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfa* , [Trewartha](/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification "Trewartha climate classification"): *Dcao* ), with warm to hot summers and chilly winters.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-94)^ Winter (November until early March) can be cold and the city receives little sunshine. Snowfall is fairly frequent in most years, and nighttime temperatures of −10 °C (14 °F) are not uncommon between mid-December and mid-February. The spring months (March and April) see variable conditions, with a rapid increase in the average temperature. The weather in late March and in April is often very agreeable during the day and fresh at night. Budapest's long summer -- lasting from May until mid-September -- is warm or very warm. Sudden heavy showers also occur, particularly in May and June. The autumn in Budapest (mid-September until late October) is characterised by little rain and long sunny days with moderate temperatures. Temperatures often turn abruptly colder in late October or early November.{#cite_ref-94}

Mean annual precipitation in Budapest is around 600 millimetres (23.5 in). On average, there are 84 days with precipitation and 1988 hours of sunshine (of a possible 4383) each year.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^^[\[95\]](#cite_note-96)^^[\[96\]](#cite_note-97)^ From March to October, average sunshine totals are roughly equal to those seen in northern Italy ([Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice")).{#cite_ref-97}

The city lies on the boundary between Zone 6 and Zone 7 in terms of the [hardiness zone](/wiki/Hardiness_zone "Hardiness zone").^[\[97\]](#cite_note-98)^^[\[98\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}

Architecture {#Architecture}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Architecture")\]

Budapest has architecturally noteworthy buildings in a wide range of styles and from distinct time periods, from the ancient times as Roman City of Aquincum in Óbuda (District III), which dates to around 89 AD, to the most modern [Palace of Arts](/wiki/Palace_of_Arts_(Budapest) "Palace of Arts (Budapest)"), the contemporary arts museum and concert hall.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-Budapest_Architecture-106)^^[\[106\]](#cite_note-107)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

Most buildings in Budapest are relatively low: in the early 2010s there were around 100 buildings higher than 45 metres (148 ft). The number of high-rise buildings is kept low by building legislation, which is aimed at preserving the historic cityscape and to meet the requirements of the [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site"). Strong rules apply to the planning, authorisation and construction of high-rise buildings and consequently much of the [inner city](/wiki/Inner_city "Inner city") does not have any. Some planners would like see an easing of the rules for the construction of skyscrapers, and the possibility of building skyscrapers outside the city's historic core has been raised.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-109)^^[\[109\]](#cite_note-110)^{#cite_ref-110}

In the chronological order of architectural styles Budapest is represented on the entire timeline, starting with the Roman City of Aquincum representing [ancient architecture](/wiki/History_of_architecture "History of architecture").

The next determinative style is the [Gothic architecture](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture") in Budapest. The few remaining Gothic buildings can be found in the Castle District. Buildings of note are no. 18, 20 and 22 on Országház Street, which date back to the 14th century and No. 31 Úri Street, which has a Gothic façade that dates back to the 15th century. Other buildings with Gothic features are the [Inner City Parish Church](/wiki/Inner_City_Parish_Church_in_Pest "Inner City Parish Church in Pest"), built in the 12th century,^[\[110\]](#cite_note-111)^ and the Mary Magdalene Church, completed in the 15th century.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-112)^ The most characteristic Gothic-style buildings are actually [Neo-Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture"), like the most well-known Budapest landmarks, the [Hungarian Parliament Building](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building")^[\[112\]](#cite_note-Steves-113)^ and the [Matthias Church](/wiki/Matthias_Church "Matthias Church"), where much of the original material was used (originally built in [Romanesque style](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture") in 1015).^[\[113\]](#cite_note-budapestbylocals.com-114)^{#cite_ref-budapestbylocals.com_114-0}

The next chapter in the history of human architecture is [Renaissance architecture](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture"). One of the earliest places to be influenced by the Renaissance style of architecture was Hungary, and Budapest in particular. The style appeared following the marriage of King [Matthias Corvinus](/wiki/Matthias_Corvinus "Matthias Corvinus") and [Beatrice of Naples](/wiki/Beatrice_of_Naples "Beatrice of Naples") in 1476. Many Italian artists, craftsmen and masons came to Buda with the new queen. Today, many of the original renaissance buildings disappeared during the varied history of Buda, but Budapest is still rich in renaissance and neo-renaissance buildings, like the famous [Hungarian State Opera House](/wiki/Hungarian_State_Opera_House "Hungarian State Opera House"), [St. Stephen's Basilica](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Basilica "St. Stephen's Basilica") and the [Hungarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Hungarian Academy of Sciences").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}

During the Turkish occupation (1541--1686), Islamic culture flourished in Budapest; multiple mosques and baths were built in the city. These were great examples of [Ottoman architecture](/wiki/Ottoman_architecture "Ottoman architecture"), which was influenced by Muslims from around the world including Turkish, Iranian, Arabian and to a larger extent, [Byzantine architecture](/wiki/Byzantine_architecture "Byzantine architecture") as well as Islamic traditions. After the Holy League conquered Budapest, they replaced most of the mosques with churches and minarets were turned into bell towers and cathedral spires. At one point the distinct sloping central square in Budapest became a bustling Oriental bazaar, which was filled with "the chatter of camel caravans on their way to Yemen and India".^[\[115\]](#cite_note-NYT1991-116)^ Budapest is in fact one of the few places in the world with functioning original [Turkish bathhouses](/wiki/Turkish_bath "Turkish bath") dating back to the 16th century, like Rudas Baths or [Király Baths](/wiki/Kir%C3%A1ly_Baths "Király Baths"). Budapest is home to the northernmost place where the [tomb](/wiki/Tomb_of_G%C3%BCl_Baba "Tomb of Gül Baba") of influential Islamic Turkish Sufi Dervish, [Gül Baba](/wiki/G%C3%BCl_Baba "Gül Baba") is found. Various cultures converged in Hungary seemed to coalesce well with each other, as if all these different cultures and architecture styles are digested into Hungary's own way of cultural blend. A precedent to show the city's self-conscious is the top section of the city's main square, named as [Szechenyi](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_square_(P%C3%A9cs) "Széchenyi square (Pécs)"). When Turks came to the city, they built mosques here which was aggressively replaced with Gothic church of St. Bertalan. The rationale of reusing the base of the former Islamic building mosque and reconstruction into Gothic Church but Islamic style architecture over it is typically Islamic are still visible. An official term for the rationale is [spolia](/wiki/Spolia "Spolia"). The mosque was called the djami of Pasha Gazi Kassim, and djami means mosque in Arabic. After Turks and Muslims were expelled and massacred from Budapest, the site was reoccupied by Christians and reformed into a church, the [Inner City Parish Church (Budapest)](/wiki/Inner_City_Parish_Church_in_Pest "Inner City Parish Church in Pest"). The [minaret](/wiki/Minaret "Minaret") and Turkish entranceway were removed. The shape of the architecture is its only hint of exotic past---"two surviving prayer niches facing Mecca and an ecumenical symbol atop its cupola: a cross rising above the Turkish crescent moon".^[\[115\]](#cite_note-NYT1991-116)^{#cite_ref-NYT1991_116-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Budapest_Hungary_08.jpg/230px-Budapest_Hungary_08.jpg)](/wiki/File:Budapest_Hungary_08.jpg) The most famous [Budapest bridge](/wiki/Bridges_of_Budapest "Bridges of Budapest"), the [Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge"), the icon of the city's 19th century development, built in 1849

After 1686, the [Baroque architecture](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") designated the dominant style of art in catholic countries from the 17th century to the 18th century.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-auto-117)^ There are many Baroque-style buildings in Budapest and one of the finest examples of preserved Baroque-style architecture is the Church of St. Anna in [Batthyhány square](/wiki/Batthy%C3%A1ny_t%C3%A9r "Batthyány tér"). An interesting part of Budapest is the less touristy Óbuda, the main square of which also has some beautiful preserved historic buildings with Baroque façades. The Castle District is another place to visit where the best-known landmark Buda Royal Palace and many other buildings were built in the Baroque style.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-auto-117)^{#cite_ref-auto_117-1}

The [Classical architecture](/wiki/Classical_architecture "Classical architecture") and [Neoclassical architecture](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") are the next in the timeline. Budapest had not one but two architects that were masters of the Classicist style. [Mihály Pollack](/wiki/Mih%C3%A1ly_Pollack "Mihály Pollack") (1773--1855) and [József Hild](/wiki/J%C3%B3zsef_Hild "József Hild") (1789--1867), built many beautiful Classicist-style buildings in the city. Some of the best examples are the [Hungarian National Museum](/wiki/Hungarian_National_Museum "Hungarian National Museum"), the [Lutheran Church of Budavár](/wiki/Lutheran_Church_of_Budav%C3%A1r "Lutheran Church of Budavár") (both designed by Pollack) and the seat of the [Hungarian president](/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Hungary "List of heads of state of Hungary"), the [Sándor Palace](/wiki/S%C3%A1ndor_Palace,_Budapest "Sándor Palace, Budapest"). The most iconic and widely known Classicist-style attraction in Budapest is the [Széchenyi Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge").^[\[117\]](#cite_note-structurae-118)^ Budapest's two most beautiful [Romantic architecture](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture#Romanticism_and_nationalism "Gothic Revival architecture") buildings are the [Great Synagogue](/wiki/Doh%C3%A1ny_Street_Synagogue "Dohány Street Synagogue") in Dohány Street and the [Vigadó Concert Hall](/wiki/Vigad%C3%B3_Concert_Hall "Vigadó Concert Hall") on the [Danube Promenade](/wiki/Danube_Promenade "Danube Promenade"), both designed by architect [Frigyes Feszl](/wiki/Frigyes_Feszl "Frigyes Feszl") (1821--1884). Another noteworthy structure is the [Budapest Western Railway Station](/wiki/Budapest-Nyugati_Railway_Terminal "Budapest-Nyugati Railway Terminal"), which was designed by August de Serres and built by the [Eiffel Company](/wiki/Eiffel_(company) "Eiffel (company)") of Paris in 1877.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)^{#cite_ref-119}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Hungarian_Parliament_Building_%2854172614480%29.jpg/220px-Hungarian_Parliament_Building_%2854172614480%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hungarian_Parliament_Building_(54172614480).jpg) The [Hungarian Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building"), completed in 1904

[Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") came into fashion in Budapest by the exhibitions which were held in and around 1896 and organised in connection with the Hungarian [Millennium](/wiki/Millennium "Millennium") celebrations.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-120)^ Art Nouveau in Hungary (*Szecesszió* in Hungarian) is a blend of several architectural styles, with a focus on Hungary's specialities. One of the leading Art Nouveau architects, [Ödön Lechner](/wiki/%C3%96d%C3%B6n_Lechner "Ödön Lechner") (1845--1914), was inspired by Indian and Syrian architecture as well as traditional Hungarian decorative designs. One of his most beautiful buildings in Budapest is the [Museum of Applied Arts](/wiki/Museum_of_Applied_Arts_(Budapest) "Museum of Applied Arts (Budapest)"). Another examples for Art Nouveau in Budapest is the [Gresham Palace](/wiki/Gresham_Palace "Gresham Palace") in front of the Chain Bridge, the [Hotel Gellért](/wiki/Hotel_Gell%C3%A9rt "Hotel Gellért"), the [Franz Liszt Academy of Music](/wiki/Franz_Liszt_Academy_of_Music "Franz Liszt Academy of Music") or [Budapest Zoo and Botanical Garden](/wiki/Budapest_Zoo_and_Botanical_Garden "Budapest Zoo and Botanical Garden").^[\[105\]](#cite_note-Budapest_Architecture-106)^{#cite_ref-Budapest_Architecture_106-1}  
It is one of the world's outstanding urban landscapes and illustrates the great periods in the history of the Hungarian capital.  
*[UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO")* ^[\[120\]](#cite_note-121)^

The second half of the 20th century also saw, under the communist regime, the construction of [blocks of flats](/wiki/Blocks_of_flats "Blocks of flats") ([panelház](/wiki/Panelh%C3%A1z "Panelház")), as in other Eastern European countries. In the 21st century, Budapest faces new challenges in its architecture. The pressure towards the high-rise buildings is unequivocal among today's world cities, but preserving Budapest's unique cityscape and its very diverse architecture, along with green areas, forces Budapest to balance between them. The [Contemporary architecture](/wiki/Contemporary_architecture "Contemporary architecture") has wide margin in the city. [Public spaces](/wiki/Public_space "Public space") attract heavy investment by business and government also, so that the city has gained entirely new (or renovated and redesigned) squares, parks and monuments, for example the city central [Kossuth Lajos square](/wiki/Kossuth_Lajos_t%C3%A9r,_Budapest "Kossuth Lajos tér, Budapest"), [Deák Ferenc square](/wiki/De%C3%A1k_Ferenc_t%C3%A9r "Deák Ferenc tér") and [Liberty Square](/wiki/Liberty_Square_(Budapest) "Liberty Square (Budapest)"). Numerous landmarks have been created in the last decade in Budapest, like the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Budapest) "National Theatre (Budapest)"), Palace of Arts, [Rákóczi Bridge](/wiki/R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_Bridge "Rákóczi Bridge"), [Megyeri Bridge](/wiki/Megyeri_Bridge "Megyeri Bridge"), [Budapest Airport Sky Court](/wiki/Budapest_Ferenc_Liszt_International_Airport#Sky_Court_between_Terminal_2A_and_2B "Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport") among others, and millions of square meters of new [office buildings](/wiki/Office_buildings "Office buildings") and [apartments](/wiki/Residential_area "Residential area"). But there are still large opportunities in [real estate development](/wiki/Real_estate_development "Real estate development") in the city.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-122)^^[\[122\]](#cite_note-123)^^[\[123\]](#cite_note-124)^{#cite_ref-124}

Contemporary Budapest is divided into 23 districts (Hungarian: *kerületek* , : *kerület* ), each with a mayor and municipal government elected separately from the general municipal government. The districts and the general municipal government have [constitutionally](/wiki/Constitution_of_Hungary "Constitution of Hungary") and legally defined, non-overlapping areas of competence. Each district has a municipally recognized name, some of which correspond to how locals call that area or neighborhood (e.g., [Belváros](/wiki/Inner_City_(Budapest) "Inner City (Budapest)"), V. district; [Terézváros](/wiki/Ter%C3%A9zv%C3%A1ros "Terézváros"), VI. district), others which (e.g., [Újbuda](/wiki/%C3%9Ajbuda "Újbuda"), XI. district) are neologisms. Street signs display the district and that neighborhood's colloquial name. The latter are often the names of villages that were gradually annexed to the city (e.g., [Sashalom](/wiki/Sashalom "Sashalom"), [Budafok](/wiki/Budafok "Budafok")) or of superseded administrative units of former boroughs.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-127)^{#cite_ref-127}

After the unification of Buda, Pest, and Óbuda in 1873, Budapest initially had 10 districts. It was during the [interwar period](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1920%E2%80%931946) "Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)") that [Károly Szendy](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/Szendy_K%C3%A1roly "hu:Szendy Károly")'s 1934-1944 mayoral administration first seriously considered annexing peripheral towns and villages. This only came about, however, after the rise of [state communism in Hungary](/wiki/Hungarian_People%27s_Republic "Hungarian People's Republic"). In 1950, for reasons of social and industrial policy---including the [Hungarian Working People's Party](/wiki/Hungarian_Working_People%27s_Party "Hungarian Working People's Party")'s desire to [proletarianize](/wiki/Proletarianization "Proletarianization") the traditionally right-wing suburbs---7 [cities with county rights](/wiki/City_with_county_rights "City with county rights") and 16 towns were annexed to the capital to form contemporary [Greater Budapest](/wiki/Greater_Budapest "Greater Budapest") (Hungarian: *Nagy-Budapest* ).^[\[127\]](#cite_note-128)^ This reorganized the city into 22 districts, a number that grew to 23 after [Soroksár](/wiki/Soroks%C3%A1r "Soroksár") seceded from [Pesterzsébet](/wiki/Pesterzs%C3%A9bet "Pesterzsébet") in 1994. The contemporary city thus consists of 6 districts in Buda, 16 in Pest, and [Csepel](/wiki/Csepel "Csepel"). Today, districts I., II., XI., and XII. in Buda and V., VI., VII., VIII., and IX. in Pest make up the city center in its broadest sense, corresponding roughly to the 1873 municipal boundaries.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-129)^^[\[129\]](#cite_note-130)^{#cite_ref-130}

Budapest's districts are numbered according to three concentric semicircles. The I. district is a small area in central Buda, including the [Castle Quarter](/wiki/Castle_Quarter_(Budapest) "Castle Quarter (Budapest)"). District II. is in Buda to the castle's northwest while district III. stretches along the northernmost part of Buda and includes the former Óbuda. District IV. continues this semicircle in northernmost Pest, but the V. district is in the very center of Pest and inaugurates a new circle that then loops back through Pest to Buda as the VI., VII., VIII., IX., XI., and XII. districts. Districts XIII., XIV., XV., XVI., XVII., XVIII., XIX., XX., XXI., and XXII. form yet another semicircle in outermost Pest. Districts X. and XXIII. form irregularities within the overall pattern.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-131)^{#cite_ref-131}

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

[Historical population]

Budapest is the most [populous city in Hungary](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Hungary "List of cities and towns in Hungary") and [one of the largest cities](/wiki/Largest_cities_of_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "Largest cities of the European Union by population within city limits") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), with a growing number of inhabitants, estimated at 1,763,913 in 2019,^[\[144\]](#cite_note-145)^ whereby inward migration exceeds outward migration.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-TIME2-12)^ These trends are also seen throughout the [Budapest metropolitan area](/wiki/Budapest_metropolitan_area "Budapest metropolitan area"), which is home to 3.3 million people.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-Budapest_City_Review2-146)^^[\[146\]](#cite_note-147)^ This amounts to about 34% of Hungary's population. In 2014, the city had a population density of 3,314 people/km^2^ (8,580 people/sq mi), rendering it the most densely populated of all municipalities in Hungary. The population density of [Elisabethtown-District VII](/wiki/Erzs%C3%A9betv%C3%A1ros "Erzsébetváros") is 30,989/km^2^ (80,260/sq mi), which has the highest population density figure in Hungary and [one of the highest in the world](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_population_density "List of cities by population density"). For comparison, the density in [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") is 25,846/km^2^.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-148)^{#cite_ref-148}

Budapest is the fourth most "dynamically growing city" by [population in Europe](/wiki/Population_of_Europe "Population of Europe"),^[\[148\]](#cite_note-149)^ and the Euromonitor predicts a population increase of almost 10% between 2005 and 2030.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-150)^ The [European Observation Network for Territorial Development and Cohesion](/wiki/European_Observation_Network_for_Territorial_Development_and_Cohesion "European Observation Network for Territorial Development and Cohesion") says Budapest's population will increase by 10% to 30% only due to migration by 2050.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-151)^ A constant inflow of migrants in recent years has fuelled population growth in Budapest. Productivity gains and the relatively large economically active share of the population explain why [household incomes](/wiki/Household_income "Household income") have increased in Budapest to a greater extent than in other parts of Hungary. Higher incomes in Budapest are reflected in the lower share of expenditure the city's inhabitants allocate to necessary spending such as on food and non-alcoholic drinks.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-Budapest_City_Review2-146)^{#cite_ref-Budapest_City_Review2_146-1}

According to the 2016 microcensus, there were 1,764,263 people living in Budapest in 907,944 dwellings.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-152)^ Some 1.6 million persons from the metropolitan area may be within Budapest's boundaries during working hours, and during special events. This fluctuation in the population is caused by hundreds of thousands of suburban residents who travel to the city for work, education, health care, and special events.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-suburbanisation-153)^{#cite_ref-suburbanisation_153-0}

By ethnicity there were 1,697,039 (96.2%) [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarians "Hungarians"), 34,909 (2%) [Germans](/wiki/Germans "Germans"), 16,592 (0.9%) [Romani](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people"), 9,117 (0.5%) [Romanians](/wiki/Romanians "Romanians") and 5,488 (0.3%) [Slovaks](/wiki/Slovaks "Slovaks").^[\[153\]](#cite_note-154)^ In Hungary people can declare multiple ethnic identities, hence the sum may exceed 100%.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-micro_2016-155)^ The share of ethnic Hungarians in Budapest (96.2%) is slightly lower than the national average (98.3%) due to the international migration.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-micro_2016-155)^{#cite_ref-micro_2016_155-1}

According to the 2011 census, 1,712,153 people (99.0%) speak [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"), of whom 1,692,815 people (97.9%) speak it as a [first language](/wiki/First_language "First language"), while 19,338 people (1.1%) speak it as a [second language](/wiki/Second_language "Second language"). Other spoken (foreign) languages were: English (536,855 speakers, 31.0%), German (266,249 speakers, 15.4%), French (56,208 speakers, 3.3%) and Russian (54,613 speakers, 3.2%).^[\[138\]](#cite_note-Census2011-139)^{#cite_ref-Census2011_139-1}

According to the same census, 1,600,585 people (92.6%) were born in Hungary, 126,036 people (7.3%) outside Hungary while the birthplace of 2,419 people (0.1%) was unknown.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-Census2011-139)^ Although only 1.7% of the population of Hungary in 2009 were foreigners, 43% of them lived in Budapest, making them 4.4% of the city's population (up from 2% in 2001).^[\[139\]](#cite_note-Novekszik-140)^ Nearly two-thirds of foreigners living in Hungary were under 40 years old. The primary motivation for this age group living in Hungary was employment.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-Novekszik-140)^{#cite_ref-Novekszik_140-2}

Budapest is home to one of the most populous [Christian communities](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") in Central Europe, numbering 698,521 people (40.4%) in 2011.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-Census2011-139)^ According to the 2011 census, there were 501,117 (29.0%) [Roman Catholics](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"), 146,756 (8.5%) [Calvinists](/wiki/Calvinism "Calvinism"), 30,293 (1.8%) [Lutherans](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism"), 16,192 (0.9%) [Greek Catholics](/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches "Eastern Catholic Churches"), 7,925 (0.5%) Jews and 3,710 (0.2%) [Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") in Budapest. 395,964 people (22.9%) were [irreligious](/wiki/Irreligion "Irreligion") while 585,475 people (33.9%) did not declare their religion.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-Census2011-139)^ The city is also home to one of the largest Jewish communities in Europe.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}

Budapest is a significant economic hub, classified as a Beta + world city in the study by the [Globalization and World Cities Research Network](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization and World Cities Research Network") and it is the second fastest-developing [urban economy](/wiki/Urban_economy "Urban economy") in Europe as GDP per capita in the city increased by 2.4 per cent and employment by 4.7 per cent compared to the previous year in 2014.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-Brookings_Institution-157)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-auto1-31)^ On national level, Budapest is the [primate city](/wiki/Primate_city "Primate city") of Hungary regarding business and the economy, accounting for 39% of the national income. The city had a [gross metropolitan product](/wiki/Gross_metropolitan_product "Gross metropolitan product") of more than $100 billion in 2015, making it one of the largest regional economies in the European Union.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-158)^ According to [Eurostat](/wiki/Eurostat "Eurostat") GDP, per capita in [purchasing power parity](/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") is 147% of the EU average in Budapest, which means €37,632 ($42,770) per capita.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-Iz.sk2-134)^ Budapest is also among the Top 100 GDP performing cities in the world, measured by [PricewaterhouseCoopers](/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers "PricewaterhouseCoopers"). The city was named as the 52nd most important business centre in the world in the [Worldwide Centres of Commerce Index](/wiki/Worldwide_Centres_of_Commerce_Index "Worldwide Centres of Commerce Index"), ahead of Beijing, São Paulo and [Shenzhen](/wiki/Shenzhen "Shenzhen") and ranking 3rd (out of 65 cities) on the [MasterCard](/wiki/MasterCard "MasterCard") [Emerging Markets Index](/wiki/Emerging_Markets_Index "Emerging Markets Index").^[\[158\]](#cite_note-MasterCard-159)^^[\[159\]](#cite_note-160)^ The city is 48th on the [UBS](/wiki/UBS "UBS") *The most expensive and richest cities in the world* list, standing before cities such as Prague, Shanghai, Kuala Lumpur and [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-161)^ In a global city competitiveness ranking by the [EIU](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit"), Budapest stands before [Tel Aviv](/wiki/Tel_Aviv "Tel Aviv"), Lisbon, Moscow and [Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg") among others.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-162)^{#cite_ref-162}

The city is a major centre for banking and finance, real estate, retailing, trade, transportation, tourism, [new media](/wiki/New_media "New media") as well as [traditional media](/wiki/Traditional_media "Traditional media"), advertising, [legal services](/wiki/Legal_services "Legal services"), [accountancy](/wiki/Accountancy "Accountancy"), insurance, fashion and the arts in Hungary and regionally. Budapest is home not only to almost all national institutions and government agencies, but also to many domestic and international companies. In 2014 there were 395.804 companies registered in the city.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-163)^ Most of these entities are headquartered in Budapest's Central Business District, in [District V](/wiki/Belv%C3%A1ros-Lip%C3%B3tv%C3%A1ros "Belváros-Lipótváros") and [District XIII](/wiki/%C3%9Ajlip%C3%B3tv%C3%A1ros "Újlipótváros"). The retail market of the city (and the country) is also concentrated in the downtown area, among others, in the two largest shopping centres in [Central and Eastern Europe](/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe "Central and Eastern Europe"), the 186,000 sqm [WestEnd City Center](/wiki/WestEnd_City_Center "WestEnd City Center") and the 180,000 sqm [Arena Plaza](/wiki/Arena_Plaza "Arena Plaza").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-164)^^[\[164\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}

Budapest has notable innovation capabilities as a technology and start-up hub. Many [start-ups](/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company") are headquartered and begin their business in the city. Some of the best known examples are [Prezi](/wiki/Prezi "Prezi"), [LogMeIn](/wiki/LogMeIn "LogMeIn") and [NNG](/wiki/NNG_(company) "NNG (company)"). Budapest is the highest ranked [Central and Eastern European](/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe "Central and Eastern Europe") city in the Innovation Cities' Top 100 index.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-Innovation-cities.com-166)^ A good indicator of the city's potential for innovation and research, is that the [European Institute of Innovation and Technology](/wiki/European_Institute_of_Innovation_and_Technology "European Institute of Innovation and Technology") chose Budapest for its headquarters, along with the UN, whose Regional Representation for Central Europe office is in the city, responsible for UN operations in seven countries.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-167)^ Moreover, the global aspect of the city's research activity is shown through the establishment of the European Chinese Research Institute in the city.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-168)^ Other important sectors also include, [natural science](/wiki/Natural_science "Natural science") research, information technology and medical research, non-profit institutions, and universities. The leading business schools and universities in Budapest, the [Budapest Business School](/wiki/Budapest_Business_School "Budapest Business School"), the [CEU Business School](/wiki/CEU_Business_School "CEU Business School") and [Corvinus University of Budapest](/wiki/Corvinus_University_of_Budapest "Corvinus University of Budapest") offer a whole range of courses in economics, finance and management in English, French, German and Hungarian.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-169)^ The [unemployment rate](/wiki/Unemployment_rate "Unemployment rate") in Budapest is by far the lowest within Hungary. It was 2.7%, with many thousands of employed foreign citizens.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-170)^{#cite_ref-170}

Budapest is among the 25 most visited cities in the world, welcoming more than 4.4 million international visitors each year,^[\[170\]](#cite_note-171)^ therefore the traditional and the congress tourism industry also deserve a mention, as they contribute greatly to the city's economy. The capital is home to many [convention centres](/wiki/Convention_center "Convention center") and there are thousands of restaurants, bars, coffee houses and party places, besides a full range of hotels. As regards restaurants, examples can be found of the highest quality [Michelin-starred](/wiki/List_of_Michelin_starred_restaurants#By_country "List of Michelin starred restaurants") restaurants, such as Onyx, Costes, Tanti and Borkonyha. The city ranked as the most liveable city in [Central and Eastern Europe](/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe "Central and Eastern Europe") on EIU's [quality of life](/wiki/Quality_of_life "Quality of life") index in 2010.{#cite_ref-171}  

### Finance and corporate location {#Finance_and_corporate_location}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Finance and corporate location")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Szabads%C3%A1g_Square%2C_Stock_Exchange_Palacve.jpg/90px-Szabads%C3%A1g_Square%2C_Stock_Exchange_Palacve.jpg)](/wiki/File:Szabads%C3%A1g_Square,_Stock_Exchange_Palacve.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Stock_Exchange_Palace_by_Ign%C3%A1c_Alp%C3%A1r%2C_detail%2C_2011_Budape%C5%A1%C5%A5_0799.jpg/214px-Stock_Exchange_Palace_by_Ign%C3%A1c_Alp%C3%A1r%2C_detail%2C_2011_Budape%C5%A1%C5%A5_0799.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stock_Exchange_Palace_by_Ign%C3%A1c_Alp%C3%A1r,_detail,_2011_Budape%C5%A1%C5%A5_0799.jpg)  
Hungarian Stock Exchange Palace on [Liberty Square](/wiki/Liberty_Square_(Budapest) "Liberty Square (Budapest)")

The [Budapest Stock Exchange](/wiki/Budapest_Stock_Exchange "Budapest Stock Exchange"), a key institution of publicly offered securities in Hungary and [Central and Eastern Europe](/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe "Central and Eastern Europe"), is situated in Budapest's CBD at [Liberty Square](/wiki/Liberty_Square_(Budapest) "Liberty Square (Budapest)"). BSE also trades other [securities](/wiki/Security_(finance) "Security (finance)") such as [government bonds](/wiki/Government_bond "Government bond") and [derivatives](/wiki/Derivative_(finance) "Derivative (finance)") as well as [stock options](/wiki/Stock_option "Stock option"). Large Hungarian [multinational corporations](/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation") headquartered in Budapest are listed on the BSE, for instance the [Fortune Global 500](/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500") firms [MOL Group](/wiki/MOL_Group "MOL Group"), the [OTP Bank](/wiki/OTP_Bank "OTP Bank"), [FHB Bank](/wiki/FHB_Mortgage_Bank "FHB Mortgage Bank"), [Gedeon Richter](/wiki/Gedeon_Richter_(company) "Gedeon Richter (company)"), [Magyar Telekom](/wiki/Magyar_Telekom "Magyar Telekom"), [CIG Pannonia](/wiki/CIG_Pannonia "CIG Pannonia"), [Zwack Unicum](/wiki/Zwack_liqueur "Zwack liqueur") and more.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-172)^ Nowadays nearly all branches of industry can be found in Budapest. Although there is no particularly special industry in the city's economy, the [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") role of the city is strong, with nearly 40 major banks being represented in the city including^[\[172\]](#cite_note-173)^ as well as those like [Bank of China](/wiki/Bank_of_China "Bank of China"), [KDB Bank](/wiki/Korea_Development_Bank "Korea Development Bank") and [Hanwha](/wiki/Hanwha "Hanwha") Bank, which are unique in the region.{#cite_ref-173}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Mol_Campus.jpg/220px-Mol_Campus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mol_Campus.jpg) [MOL Campus](/wiki/MOL_Campus "MOL Campus"), a neomodern skyscraper and the headquarters of [MOL Group](/wiki/MOL_(company) "MOL (company)")

Many international banks and financial service providers also support the financial industry of Budapest, firms such as [Citigroup](/wiki/Citigroup "Citigroup"), [Morgan Stanley](/wiki/Morgan_Stanley "Morgan Stanley"), [GE Capital](/wiki/GE_Capital "GE Capital"), [Deutsche Bank](/wiki/Deutsche_Bank "Deutsche Bank"), [Sberbank](/wiki/Sberbank "Sberbank"), [ING Group](/wiki/ING_Group "ING Group"), [Allianz](/wiki/Allianz "Allianz"), [KBC Group](/wiki/KBC_Group "KBC Group"), [UniCredit](/wiki/UniCredit "UniCredit") and [MSCI](/wiki/MSCI "MSCI") among others. Another particularly strong industry in the capital city is the [biotechnology](/wiki/Biotechnology "Biotechnology") and [pharmaceutical industry](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry "Pharmaceutical industry"). There are also traditionally strong domestic companies in Budapest such as Egis, Gedeon Richter, Chinoin as well as international biotechnology corporations such as [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer "Pfizer"), [Teva](/wiki/Teva_Pharmaceutical_Industries "Teva Pharmaceutical Industries"), [Novartis](/wiki/Novartis "Novartis"), [Sanofi](/wiki/Sanofi "Sanofi"), which also have [R\&D](/wiki/R%26D "R&D") and production divisions here. Further high-tech industries, involved in [software development](/wiki/Software_development "Software development") and engineering are notable as well. [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia_Networks "Nokia Networks"), [Ericsson](/wiki/Ericsson "Ericsson"), [Bosch](/wiki/Robert_Bosch_GmbH "Robert Bosch GmbH"), [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") and [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") employ thousands of engineers in research and development in the city. [Game design](/wiki/Game_design "Game design") is also strongly represented with headquarters of domestic companies [Digital Reality](/wiki/Digital_Reality "Digital Reality"), [Black Hole](/wiki/Black_Hole_Entertainment "Black Hole Entertainment") and the studios of [Crytek](/wiki/Crytek "Crytek") and [Gameloft](/wiki/Gameloft "Gameloft"). Apart from the above, there are regional headquarters of global firms such as [Alcoa](/wiki/Alcoa "Alcoa"), [General Motors](/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors"), [General Electric](/wiki/General_Electric "General Electric"), [ExxonMobil](/wiki/ExxonMobil "ExxonMobil"), [BP](/wiki/BP "BP"), [BT](/wiki/BT_Group "BT Group"), [Flextronics](/wiki/Flextronics "Flextronics"), [Panasonic](/wiki/Panasonic "Panasonic"), [Huawei](/wiki/Huawei "Huawei"), [Knorr-Bremse](/wiki/Knorr-Bremse "Knorr-Bremse"), [Liberty Global](/wiki/Liberty_Global "Liberty Global"), [Tata Consultancy](/wiki/Tata_Consultancy_Services "Tata Consultancy Services"), [Aegon](/wiki/Aegon_N.V. "Aegon N.V."), [WizzAir](/wiki/WizzAir "WizzAir"), [TriGránit](/wiki/TriGr%C3%A1nit "TriGránit"), [MVM Group](/wiki/MVM_Group "MVM Group") and [Graphisoft](/wiki/Graphisoft "Graphisoft"). There is a base for major international companies including, but not limited to, [Nissan](/wiki/Nissan "Nissan") CEE, [Volvo](/wiki/Volvo "Volvo"), [Saab](/wiki/Saab_Automobile "Saab Automobile") and [Ford](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company").
