Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") meets with Hungarian President [László Sólyom](/wiki/L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_S%C3%B3lyom "László Sólyom") at [Sándor Palace](/wiki/S%C3%A1ndor_Palace,_Budapest "Sándor Palace, Budapest") in Budapest. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/S%C3%A1ndor-palota_naps%C3%BCt%C3%A9sben.jpg/220px-S%C3%A1ndor-palota_naps%C3%BCt%C3%A9sben.jpg)](/wiki/File:S%C3%A1ndor-palota_naps%C3%BCt%C3%A9sben.jpg) [Sándor Palace](/wiki/S%C3%A1ndor_Palace "Sándor Palace"), the official residence and workspace of the [president of Hungary](/wiki/President_of_Hungary "President of Hungary")

As the capital of Hungary, Budapest is the seat of the country's [national government](/wiki/Central_government "Central government"). The President of Hungary resides at the Sándor Palace in the District I (Buda Castle District),^[\[173\]](#cite_note-174)^ while the office of the Hungarian Prime Minister is in the Carmelite Monastery in the Castle District.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-175)^ [Government ministries](/wiki/Ministry_(government_department) "Ministry (government department)") are all located in various parts of the city, most of them are in the District V, [Leopoldtown](/wiki/Inner_City_(Budapest) "Inner City (Budapest)"). The [National Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Hungary) "National Assembly (Hungary)") is seated in the Hungarian Parliament, which also located in the District V.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-176)^ The [President of the National Assembly](/wiki/List_of_Speakers_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Hungary "List of Speakers of the National Assembly of Hungary"), the third-highest public official in Hungary, is also seated in the largest building in the country, in the Hungarian Parliament.{#cite_ref-176}

Hungary's highest courts are located in Budapest. The Curia ([supreme court](/wiki/Supreme_court "Supreme court") of Hungary), the highest court in the judicial order, which reviews criminal and civil cases, is located in the District V, Leopoldtown. Under the authority of its president it has three departments: criminal, civil and administrative-labour law departments. Each department has various chambers. The Curia guarantees the uniform application of law. The decisions of the Curia on uniform [jurisdiction](/wiki/Jurisdiction "Jurisdiction") are binding for other courts.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-177)^ The second most important judicial authority, the National Judicial Council, is also housed in the District V, with the tasks of controlling the financial management of the judicial administration and the courts and giving an opinion on the practice of the president of the National Office for the Judiciary and the Curia deciding about the applications of judges and court leaders, among others.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-178)^ The [Constitutional Court of Hungary](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Hungary "Constitutional Court of Hungary") is one of the highest level actors independent of the politics in the country. The Constitutional Court serves as the main body for the protection of the [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Hungary "Constitution of Hungary"), its tasks being the review of the constitutionality of statutes. The Constitutional Court performs its tasks independently. With its own budget and its judges being elected by Parliament it does not constitute a part of the ordinary judicial system. The constitutional court passes on the [constitutionality](/wiki/Constitutionality "Constitutionality") of laws, and there is no right of appeal on these decisions.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-179)^{#cite_ref-179}

Budapest hosts the main and regional headquarters of many international organizations as well, including [United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees](/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees "United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees"), [Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations](/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization_of_the_United_Nations "Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations"), European Institute of Innovation and Technology, [European Police Academy](/wiki/European_Police_College "European Police College"), [International Centre for Democratic Transition](/wiki/International_Centre_for_Democratic_Transition "International Centre for Democratic Transition"), [Institute of International Education](/wiki/Institute_of_International_Education "Institute of International Education"), [International Labour Organization](/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization"), [International Organization for Migration](/wiki/International_Organization_for_Migration "International Organization for Migration"), [International Red Cross](/wiki/International_Federation_of_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Societies "International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies"), Regional Environmental Center for Central and Eastern Europe, [Danube Commission](/wiki/Danube_Commission_(1948) "Danube Commission (1948)") and even others.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-180)^ The city is also home to more than 100 [embassies](/wiki/Embassy "Embassy") and representative bodies as an international political actor.{#cite_ref-180}

Environmental issues have a high priority among Budapest's politics. Institutions such as the Regional Environmental Center for Central and Eastern Europe, located in Budapest, are very important assets.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-181)^ To decrease the use of cars and [greenhouse gas emissions](/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions "Greenhouse gas emissions"), the city has worked to improve public transportation, and nowadays the city has one of the highest [mass transit](/wiki/Mass_transit "Mass transit") usage in Europe. Budapest has one of the best public transport systems in Europe with an efficient network of buses, [trolleys](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus"), trams and [subway](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit"). Budapest has an above-average proportion of people commuting on public transport or walking and cycling for European cities.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-A_good_place_to_live_–_Budapest-182)^ Riding on [bike paths](/wiki/Bike_paths "Bike paths") is one of the best ways to see Budapest -- there are about 180 kilometres (110 miles) of bicycle paths in the city, fitting into the [EuroVelo](/wiki/EuroVelo "EuroVelo") system.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}

Crime in Budapest is investigated by different bodies. [United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime](/wiki/United_Nations_Office_on_Drugs_and_Crime "United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime") notes in their 2011 Global Study on Homicide that, according to criminal justice sources, the homicide rate in Hungary, calculated based on UN population estimates, was 1.4 in 2009, compared to Canada's rate of 1.8 that same year.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-184)^ The homicide rate in Budapest is below the EU capital cities' average according to [WHO](/wiki/WHO "WHO") also.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-185)^ However, [organised crime](/wiki/Organised_crime "Organised crime") is associated with the city, the Institute of Defence in a UN study named Budapest as one of the "global epicentres" of illegal pornography, money laundering and contraband tobacco, and also a negotiation center for international crime group leaders.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}  

### City governance {#City_governance}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: City governance")\]  
See also: [Mayor of Budapest](/wiki/Mayor_of_Budapest "Mayor of Budapest"), [Lord Mayor of Budapest](/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_Budapest "Lord Mayor of Budapest"), and [General Assembly of Budapest](/wiki/General_Assembly_of_Budapest "General Assembly of Budapest")

|---|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------|---|

|   | **[Fidesz](/wiki/Fidesz "Fidesz") -- Hungarian Civic Union**                                                                                                                 | 10 seats        |
|   | **[Tisza Party](/wiki/Tisza_Party "Tisza Party")**                                                                                                                           | 10 seats        |
|   | **[DK--MSZP--P](/wiki/DK%E2%80%93MSZP%E2%80%93Dialogue_Alliance "DK–MSZP–Dialogue Alliance")**                                                                               | Mayor + 6 seats |
|   | **[VDB](/wiki/With_D%C3%A1vid_Vit%C3%A9zy_for_Budapest "With Dávid Vitézy for Budapest")--[LMP](/wiki/LMP_%E2%80%93_Hungary%27s_Green_Party "LMP – Hungary's Green Party")** | 3 seats         |

Budapest has been a [metropolitan municipality](/wiki/Metropolitan_municipality "Metropolitan municipality") with a mayor-council form of government since its consolidation in 1873, but Budapest also holds a special status as a county-level government, and also special within that, as holds a capital-city territory status.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-187)^ In Budapest, the central government is responsible for the [urban planning](/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning"), [statutory planning](/wiki/Statutory_planning "Statutory planning"), public transport, housing, [waste management](/wiki/Waste_management "Waste management"), municipal taxes, correctional institutions, libraries, public safety, recreational facilities, among others. The Mayor is responsible for all city services, police and fire protection, enforcement of all city and state laws within the city, and administration of public property and most public agencies. Besides, each of Budapest' twenty-three districts has its own town hall and a directly elected council and the directly elected mayor of district.^[\[1\]](#cite_note-municipality-1)^{#cite_ref-municipality_1-1}

The Mayor of Budapest is [Gergely Karácsony](/wiki/Gergely_Kar%C3%A1csony "Gergely Karácsony") who was elected on 13 October 2019. The mayor and members of General Assembly are elected to five-year terms.^[\[1\]](#cite_note-municipality-1)^ The Budapest General Assembly is a [unicameral](/wiki/Unicameral "Unicameral") body consisting of 33 members, which consist of the 23 mayors of the districts, 9 from the electoral lists of political parties, plus Mayor of Budapest (the Mayor is elected directly). Each term for the mayor and assembly members lasts five years.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-188)^ Submitting the budget of Budapest is the responsibility of the Mayor and the deputy-mayor in charge of finance. The latest, 2014 budget was approved with 18 supporting votes from ruling Fidesz and 14 votes against by the opposition lawmakers.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}  

Main sights and tourism {#Main_sights_and_tourism}
--------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Main sights and tourism")\]  
See also: [List of sights and historic places in Budapest](/wiki/List_of_sights_and_historic_places_in_Budapest "List of sights and historic places in Budapest") and [List of tourist attractions in Budapest](/wiki/List_of_tourist_attractions_in_Budapest "List of tourist attractions in Budapest")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Saint_Stephen%27s_Basilica%2C_W%2C_Budapest_%2819%29_%2813229766465%29.jpg/220px-Saint_Stephen%27s_Basilica%2C_W%2C_Budapest_%2819%29_%2813229766465%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Saint_Stephen%27s_Basilica,_W,_Budapest_(19)_(13229766465).jpg) [St. Stephen's Basilica](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Basilica "St. Stephen's Basilica")

Budapest is widely known for its well-kept pre-war cityscape, with a great variety of streets and landmarks in [classical architecture](/wiki/Classical_architecture "Classical architecture").

The most well-known sight of the capital is the [neo-Gothic](/wiki/Neo-Gothic "Neo-Gothic") [Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building"), the biggest building in Hungary with its 268 metres (879 ft) length, also holding (since 2001) the [Hungarian Crown Jewels](/wiki/Holy_Crown_of_Hungary "Holy Crown of Hungary").

[Saint Stephen's Basilica](/wiki/Saint_Stephen%27s_Basilica "Saint Stephen's Basilica") is the most important religious building of the city, where the [Holy Right Hand](/w/index.php?title=Holy_Right_Hand&action=edit&redlink=1 "Holy Right Hand (page does not exist)") of Hungary's first king, [Saint Stephen](/wiki/Stephen_I_of_Hungary "Stephen I of Hungary") is on display as well.

[Hungarian cuisine](/wiki/Hungarian_cuisine "Hungarian cuisine") and café culture can be seen and tasted in many places, like [Gerbeaud Café](/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Gerbeaud "Café Gerbeaud"), the *Százéves* , *Biarritz* , *Fortuna* , *Alabárdos* , *Arany Szarvas* , *[Gundel](/wiki/Gundel "Gundel")* and the world-famous Mátyás-pince restaurants and beer bars.

There are Roman remains at the [Aquincum Museum](/wiki/Aquincum_Museum "Aquincum Museum"), and historic furniture at the [Nagytétény Castle Museum](/wiki/Nagyt%C3%A9t%C3%A9ny_Castle_Museum "Nagytétény Castle Museum"), just 2 of 223 museums in Budapest. Another historical museum is the [House of Terror](/wiki/House_of_Terror "House of Terror"), hosted in the building that was the venue of the [Nazi Headquarters](/wiki/Nazi_Headquarters "Nazi Headquarters"). The Castle Hill, the River Danube embankments and the whole of Andrássy út have been officially recognized as [UNESCO World Heritage Sites](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites "UNESCO World Heritage Sites").

Castle Hill and the [Castle District](/wiki/Castle_District,_Buda "Castle District, Buda"); there are three churches here, six museums, and a host of interesting buildings, streets and squares. The former Royal Palace is one of the symbols of Hungary -- and has been the scene of battles and wars ever since the 13th century. Nowadays it houses two museums and the [National Széchenyi Library](/wiki/National_Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Library "National Széchenyi Library"). The nearby Sándor Palace contains the offices and official residence of the [President of Hungary](/wiki/President_of_Hungary "President of Hungary"). The seven-hundred-year-old Matthias Church is one of the jewels of Budapest, it is in neo-Gothic style, decorated with coloured shingles and elegant pinnacles. Next to it is an equestrian statue of the first king of Hungary, King Saint Stephen, and behind that is the [Fisherman's Bastion](/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Bastion "Fisherman's Bastion"), built in 1905 by the architect [Frigyes Schulek](/wiki/Frigyes_Schulek "Frigyes Schulek"), the Fishermen's Bastions owes its name to the namesake corporation that during the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") was responsible of the defence of this part of ramparts, from where opens out a panoramic view of the whole city. Statues of the [Turul](/wiki/Turul "Turul"), the mythical guardian bird of Hungary, can be found in both the Castle District and the [Twelfth District](/wiki/Hegyvid%C3%A9k "Hegyvidék").

In Pest, arguably the most important sight is Andrássy út. This Avenue is an elegant 2.5 kilometres (2 miles) long tree-lined street that covers the distance from Deák Ferenc tér to the Heroes Square. This Avenue overlooks many important sites. It is a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site"). As far as [Kodály körönd](/wiki/Kod%C3%A1ly_k%C3%B6r%C3%B6nd "Kodály körönd") and [Oktogon](/wiki/Oktogon_(intersection) "Oktogon (intersection)") both sides are lined with large shops and flats built close together. Between there and Heroes' Square the houses are detached and altogether grander. Under the whole runs continental Europe's oldest Underground railway, most of whose stations retain their original appearance. Heroes' Square is dominated by the [Millenary Monument](/wiki/H%C5%91s%C3%B6k_tere#Millenary_Monument "Hősök tere"), with the [Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier "Tomb of the Unknown Soldier") in front. To the sides are the [Museum of Fine Arts](/wiki/Museum_of_Fine_Arts_(Budapest) "Museum of Fine Arts (Budapest)") and the [Kunsthalle Budapest](/wiki/Kunsthalle_Budapest "Kunsthalle Budapest"), and behind City Park opens out, with [Vajdahunyad Castle](/wiki/Vajdahunyad_Castle "Vajdahunyad Castle"). One of the jewels of Andrássy út is the Hungarian State Opera House. [Statue Park](/wiki/Statue_Park "Statue Park"), a theme park with striking statues of the [Communist era](/wiki/Communist_era "Communist era"), is located just outside the main city and is accessible by public transport.

The Dohány Street Synagogue is the largest synagogue in Europe, and the second largest active synagogue in the world.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-190)^ The synagogue is located in the Jewish district taking up several blocks in central Budapest bordered by Király utca, Wesselényi utca, [Grand Boulevard](/wiki/Grand_Boulevard_(Budapest) "Grand Boulevard (Budapest)") and Bajcsy Zsilinszky road. It was built in moorish revival style in 1859 and has a [seating capacity](/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") of 3,000. Adjacent to it is a sculpture reproducing a weeping willow tree in steel to commemorate the Hungarian victims of the [Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Hungary "The Holocaust in Hungary").{#cite_ref-190}

The city is also home to the largest medicinal [bath](/wiki/Roman_baths "Roman baths") in Europe ([Széchenyi Medicinal Bath](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Medicinal_Bath "Széchenyi Medicinal Bath")) and the third largest Parliament building in the world, once the largest in the world. Other attractions are the [bridges of the capital](/wiki/Bridges_of_Budapest "Bridges of Budapest"). Seven bridges provide crossings over the Danube, and from north to south are: the [Árpád Bridge](/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1d_Bridge "Árpád Bridge") (built in 1950 at the north of Margaret Island); the [Margaret Bridge](/wiki/Margaret_Bridge "Margaret Bridge") (built in 1901, destroyed during the war by an explosion and then rebuilt in 1948); the Chain Bridge (built in 1849, destroyed during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and then rebuilt in 1949); the [Elisabeth Bridge](/wiki/Elisabeth_Bridge "Elisabeth Bridge") (completed in 1903 and dedicated to the murdered [Queen Elisabeth](/wiki/Empress_Elisabeth_of_Austria "Empress Elisabeth of Austria"), it was destroyed by the Germans during the war and replaced with a new bridge in 1964); the [Liberty Bridge](/wiki/Liberty_Bridge_(Budapest) "Liberty Bridge (Budapest)") (opened in 1896 and rebuilt in 1989 in Art Nouveau style); the [Petőfi Bridge](/wiki/Pet%C5%91fi_Bridge "Petőfi Bridge") (completed in 1937, destroyed during the war and rebuilt in 1952); the Rákóczi Bridge (completed in 1995). Most remarkable for their beauty are the Margaret Bridge, the Chain Bridge and the Liberty Bridge. The world's largest panorama photograph was created in (and of) Budapest in 2010.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}

Tourists visiting Budapest can receive free maps and information from the nonprofit Budapest Festival and Tourism Center at its info-points.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-192)^ The info centers also offer the Budapest Card which allows free public transit and discounts for several museums, restaurants and other places of interest. Cards are available for 24-, 48- or 72-hour durations.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-193)^ The city is also well known for its ruin bars both day and night.{#cite_ref-193}  

### Squares {#Squares}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Squares")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Virgin_Mary_and_Trinity_group%2C_Holy_Trinity_column%2C_2016_Budapest.jpg/220px-Virgin_Mary_and_Trinity_group%2C_Holy_Trinity_column%2C_2016_Budapest.jpg)](/wiki/File:Virgin_Mary_and_Trinity_group,_Holy_Trinity_column,_2016_Budapest.jpg) The Holy Trinity column in the [Holy Trinity Square](/w/index.php?title=Holy_Trinity_Square,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Holy Trinity Square, Budapest (page does not exist)"), [Buda Castle Hill](/wiki/V%C3%A1rhegy "Várhegy") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Batthy%C3%A1ny_Eternal_Flame.jpg/220px-Batthy%C3%A1ny_Eternal_Flame.jpg)](/wiki/File:Batthy%C3%A1ny_Eternal_Flame.jpg) The [Batthyány eternal flame](/wiki/Batthy%C3%A1ny%27s_sanctuary_lamp "Batthyány's sanctuary lamp"), located in [Lipótváros](/wiki/Lip%C3%B3tv%C3%A1ros "Lipótváros") commemorates the place where [Lajos Batthyány](/wiki/Lajos_Batthy%C3%A1ny "Lajos Batthyány") first real [prime minister of Hungary](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Hungary "Prime Minister of Hungary") was executed.

In Budapest there are many smaller and larger [squares](/wiki/Public_space "Public space"), the most significant of which are [Heroes' Square](/wiki/H%C5%91s%C3%B6k_tere "Hősök tere"), [Kossuth Square](/wiki/Kossuth_Square "Kossuth Square"), [Liberty Square](/wiki/Liberty_Square_(Budapest) "Liberty Square (Budapest)"), [St. Stephen's Square](/w/index.php?title=St._Stephen%27s_Square,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "St. Stephen's Square, Budapest (page does not exist)"), [Ferenc Deák Square](/wiki/De%C3%A1k_Ferenc_t%C3%A9r "Deák Ferenc tér"), [Vörösmarty Square](/wiki/V%C3%B6r%C3%B6smarty_t%C3%A9r "Vörösmarty tér"), [Erzsébet Square](/w/index.php?title=Erzs%C3%A9bet_Square&action=edit&redlink=1 "Erzsébet Square (page does not exist)"), [St. George's Square](/w/index.php?title=St._George%27s_Square,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "St. George's Square, Budapest (page does not exist)") and [Széchenyi István Square](/w/index.php?title=Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Istv%C3%A1n_Square,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Széchenyi István Square, Budapest (page does not exist)"). The Heroes' Square at the end of [Andrássy Avenue](/wiki/Andr%C3%A1ssy_%C3%BAt "Andrássy út") is the largest and most influential square in the capital, with the [Millennium Monument](/w/index.php?title=Millennium_Monument,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Millennium Monument, Budapest (page does not exist)") in the center, and the [Museum of Fine Arts](/wiki/Museum_of_Fine_Arts_(Budapest) "Museum of Fine Arts (Budapest)") and [The Hall of Art](/wiki/Hall_of_Art,_Budapest "Hall of Art, Budapest"). Kossuth Square is a symbolic place of the Hungarian statehood, the [Hungarian Parliament Building](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building"), the [Palace of Justice](/w/index.php?title=Palace_of_Justice,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Palace of Justice, Budapest (page does not exist)") and the [Ministry of Agriculture](/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Agriculture,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ministry of Agriculture, Budapest (page does not exist)"). The Liberty Square is located in the [Belváros-Lipótváros](/wiki/Belv%C3%A1ros-Lip%C3%B3tv%C3%A1ros "Belváros-Lipótváros") District (Inner City District), as one of Budapest's most beautiful squares. There are buildings such as the [Hungarian National Bank](/wiki/Hungarian_National_Bank "Hungarian National Bank"), the [embassy of the United States](/w/index.php?title=Embassy_of_the_United_States_in_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Embassy of the United States in Budapest (page does not exist)"), the [Stock Exchange Palace](/w/index.php?title=Stock_Exchange_Palace,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stock Exchange Palace, Budapest (page does not exist)"), as well as numerous statues and monuments such as the Soviet War Memorial, the Statue of [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") or the controversial [Monument to the victims of the German occupation](/w/index.php?title=Monument_to_the_victims_of_the_German_occupation,_Budapest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Monument to the victims of the German occupation, Budapest (page does not exist)"). In the St. Stephen's Square is the [St. Stephen's Basilica](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Basilica "St. Stephen's Basilica"), the square is connected by a walking street, the [Zrínyi Street](/w/index.php?title=Zr%C3%ADnyi_Street&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zrínyi Street (page does not exist)"), to the Széchenyi István Square at the foot of [The Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge"). The [Hungarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Hungarian Academy of Sciences") and the [Gresham Palace](/wiki/Gresham_Palace "Gresham Palace") and the [Ministry of Interior](/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Hungary) "Ministry of Interior (Hungary)") are also located here. Deák Ferenc Square is a central square of the capital, a major transport hub, where three [Budapest subways](/wiki/Budapest_Metro "Budapest Metro") meet. Here is the oldest and best known Evangelical Church of Budapest, the [Deák Ferenc Square Lutheran Church](/w/index.php?title=De%C3%A1k_Ferenc_Square_Lutheran_Church&action=edit&redlink=1 "Deák Ferenc Square Lutheran Church (page does not exist)"). Vörösmarty Square is located in Belváros-Lipótváros District (Inner City District) behind the [Vigadó of Pest](/wiki/Vigad%C3%B3_of_Pest "Vigadó of Pest") as one of the endpoints of [Váci Street](/wiki/V%C3%A1ci_Street "Váci Street"). The [Confectionery Gerbeaud](/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Gerbeaud "Café Gerbeaud") is here, and the annual Christmas Fair is held in the Square, as well as is the centre of the [Holiday Book Week](/w/index.php?title=Holiday_Book_Week&action=edit&redlink=1 "Holiday Book Week (page does not exist)").  

### Parks and gardens {#Parks_and_gardens}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Parks and gardens")\]  
See also: [Category:Parks in Budapest](/wiki/Category:Parks_in_Budapest "Category:Parks in Budapest")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Mujegpalya_Ice_Rink.jpg/250px-Mujegpalya_Ice_Rink.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mujegpalya_Ice_Rink.jpg) The [City Park Ice Rink](/wiki/City_Park_Ice_Rink "City Park Ice Rink"), located in the [City Park](/wiki/City_Park_(Budapest) "City Park (Budapest)"); the [Vajdahunyad Castle](/wiki/Vajdahunyad_Castle "Vajdahunyad Castle") is in the background.

Budapest has many [municipal parks](/wiki/Municipal_parks "Municipal parks") and most have playgrounds for children and seasonal activities like skating in the winter and boating in the summer. Access from the city center is quick and easy with the [Millennium Underground](/wiki/Line_1_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 1 (Budapest Metro)"). Budapest has a complex park system, with various lands operated by the Budapest City Gardening Ltd.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-parks-194)^ The wealth of greenspace afforded by Budapest's parks is further augmented by a network of open spaces containing forest, streams, and lakes that are set aside as natural areas which lie not far from the inner city, including the Budapest Zoo and Botanical Garden (established in 1866) in the City Park.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-195)^ The most notable and popular parks in Budapest are the [City Park](/wiki/City_Park_(Budapest) "City Park (Budapest)") which was established in 1751 (302 acres) along with [Andrássy Avenue](/wiki/Andr%C3%A1ssy_Avenue "Andrássy Avenue"),^[\[195\]](#cite_note-196)^ the [Margaret Island](/wiki/Margaret_Island "Margaret Island") in the Danube (238 acres or 96 hectares),^[\[196\]](#cite_note-197)^ the [People's Park](/wiki/People%27s_Park_(Budapest) "People's Park (Budapest)"), the [Római Part](/wiki/R%C3%B3mai_Part_(Roman_Beach) "Római Part (Roman Beach)"), and the Kopaszi Dam.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}

The [Buda Hills](/wiki/Buda_Hills "Buda Hills") also offer a variety of outdoor activities and views. A place frequented by locals is [Normafa](/wiki/Normafa "Normafa"), offering activities for all seasons. With a modest ski run, it is also used by skiers and snowboarders -- if there is enough snowfall in winter.  

### Islands {#Islands}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Islands")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Girl_in_the_Margit-sziget_Garden_%285978988972%29.jpg/220px-Girl_in_the_Margit-sziget_Garden_%285978988972%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Girl_in_the_Margit-sziget_Garden_(5978988972).jpg) Park on [Margaret Island](/wiki/Margaret_Island "Margaret Island") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Margitsziget_2018-ban_-_l%C3%A9gi_fot%C3%B3.jpg/220px-Margitsziget_2018-ban_-_l%C3%A9gi_fot%C3%B3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Margitsziget_2018-ban_-_l%C3%A9gi_fot%C3%B3.jpg) Aerial panorama with [Margaret Island](/wiki/Margaret_Island "Margaret Island") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Budapest_Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Baths_R01.jpg/250px-Budapest_Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Baths_R01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Budapest_Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Baths_R01.jpg) [Széchenyi Thermal Bath](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Medicinal_Bath "Széchenyi Medicinal Bath") in the [City Park](/wiki/City_Park_(Budapest) "City Park (Budapest)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Budapest_Gell%C3%A9rtbad_2.JPG/220px-Budapest_Gell%C3%A9rtbad_2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Budapest_Gell%C3%A9rtbad_2.JPG) Gate of the Gellért Spa

A number of islands can be found on the Danube in Budapest:

* [Margaret Island](/wiki/Margaret_Island "Margaret Island") ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Margit-sziget* [\[ˈmɒrɡit.siɡɛt\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Hungarian "Help:IPA/Hungarian")) is a 2.5 km (1.6 mi) long island and 0.965 square kilometres (238 acres) in area. The island mostly consists of a park and is a popular recreational area for tourists and locals alike. The island lies between Margaret Bridge (south) and Árpád Bridge (north). Dance clubs, swimming pools, an [aqua park](/wiki/Water_park "Water park"), athletic and fitness centres, bicycle and running tracks can be found around the Island. During the day the island is occupied by people doing sports, or just resting.
* [Csepel Island](/wiki/Csepel_Island "Csepel Island") ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Csepel-sziget* [\[ˈt͡ʃɛpɛlsiɡɛt\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Hungarian "Help:IPA/Hungarian")) is the largest island of the River Danube in Hungary. It is 48 km (30 mi) long; its width is 6 to 8 km (4 to 5 mi) and its area comprises 257 km^2^ (99 sq mi). However, only the northern tip of the island is inside the city limits.
* [Hajógyári Island](/wiki/Haj%C3%B3gy%C3%A1ri_Island "Hajógyári Island") ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Hajógyári-sziget* [\[ˈhɒjoːɟaːrisiɡɛt\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Hungarian "Help:IPA/Hungarian")), also known as Óbuda Island ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Óbudai-sziget* ), is a human-made island located in the third district. This island hosts many activities such as: wake-boarding, jet-skiing during the day, and [dance clubs](/wiki/Nightclub "Nightclub") during the night. This is the island where the famous [Sziget Festival](/wiki/Sziget_Festival "Sziget Festival") takes place, hosting hundreds of performances per year. Around 400,000 visitors attended the last festival. Many building projects are taking place to make this island into one of the biggest entertainment centres of Europe. The plan is to build [apartment buildings](/wiki/Apartment_building "Apartment building"), hotels, casinos and a marina.
* [Molnár Island](/w/index.php?title=Moln%C3%A1r_Island&action=edit&redlink=1 "Molnár Island (page does not exist)") \[[hu](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moln%C3%A1r-sziget "hu:Molnár-sziget")\] ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Molnár-sziget*) is an island in the channel of the Danube that separates Csepel Island from the east bank of the river.

The islands of [Palotai Island](/w/index.php?title=Palotai_Island&action=edit&redlink=1 "Palotai Island (page does not exist)") \[[hu](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palotai-sziget "hu:Palotai-sziget")\], [Nép Island](/w/index.php?title=N%C3%A9p_Island&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nép Island (page does not exist)") \[[hu](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9psziget "hu:Népsziget")\], and [Háros Island](/w/index.php?title=H%C3%A1ros_Island&action=edit&redlink=1 "Háros Island (page does not exist)") \[[hu](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%C3%A1ros-sziget "hu:Háros-sziget")\] also formerly existed within the city, but have been joined to the mainland.

The [Ínség Rock](/w/index.php?title=%C3%8Dns%C3%A9g_Rock&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ínség Rock (page does not exist)") \[[hu](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%8Dns%C3%A9g-szikla "hu:Ínség-szikla")\] ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Ínség-szikla* ) is a [reef](/wiki/Reef "Reef") in the Danube close to the shore under the [Gellért Hill](/wiki/Gell%C3%A9rt_Hill "Gellért Hill"). It is only exposed during drought periods when the river level is very low.

Just outside the city boundary to the north lies the large [Szentendre Island](/wiki/Szentendre_Island "Szentendre Island") ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Szentendrei-sziget* ) and the much smaller [Lupa Island](/wiki/Lupa_Island_(Hungary) "Lupa Island (Hungary)") ([Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_language "Hungarian language"): *Lupa-sziget*).  

### Spas {#Spas}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Spas")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Panoramic_view_of_Budapest_2014.jpg/1300px-Panoramic_view_of_Budapest_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panoramic_view_of_Budapest_2014.jpg "Night panorama from Gellért Hill with the illuminated Buda Castle, Matthias Church, Danube Chain Bridge, Parliament, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, St. Stephen's Basilica, Budapest Eye, and Vigadó Concert Hall")  
[](/wiki/File:Panoramic_view_of_Budapest_2014.jpg "File:Panoramic view of Budapest 2014.jpg")
Night panorama from [Gellért Hill](/wiki/Gell%C3%A9rt_Hill "Gellért Hill") with the illuminated [Buda Castle](/wiki/Buda_Castle "Buda Castle"), [Matthias Church](/wiki/Matthias_Church "Matthias Church"), [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") [Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge"), [Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building"), [Hungarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Hungarian Academy of Sciences"), [St. Stephen's Basilica](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Basilica "St. Stephen's Basilica"), Budapest Eye, and [Vigadó Concert Hall](/wiki/Vigad%C3%B3_Concert_Hall "Vigadó Concert Hall")

One of the reasons the Romans first colonised the area immediately to the west of the River Danube and established their regional capital at Aquincum (now part of Óbuda, in northern Budapest) is so that they could use and enjoy the thermal springs. There are still ruins visible today of the enormous baths that were built during that period. The new baths that were constructed during the Turkish period (1541--1686) served both bathing and medicinal purposes, and some of these are still in use to this day.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-199)^^[\[199\]](#cite_note-200)^{#cite_ref-200}

Budapest gained its reputation as a city of [spas](/wiki/Spas_in_Budapest "Spas in Budapest") in the 1920s, following the first realisation of the economic potential of the thermal waters in drawing in visitors. Indeed, in 1934 Budapest was officially ranked as a "City of Spas". Today, the baths are mostly frequented by the older generation, as, with the exception of the "Magic Bath" and "Cinetrip" water discos, young people tend to prefer the lidos which are open in the summer.

Construction of the Király Baths started in 1565, and most of the present-day building dates from the Turkish period, including most notably the fine cupola-topped pool.

The [Rudas Baths](/wiki/Rudas_Baths "Rudas Baths") are centrally placed -- in the narrow strip of land between Gellért Hill and the River Danube -- and also an outstanding example of architecture dating from the Turkish period. The central feature is an octagonal pool over which light shines from a 10 metres (33 ft) diameter cupola, supported by eight pillars.

The [Gellért Baths](/wiki/Gell%C3%A9rt_Baths "Gellért Baths") and Hotel were built in 1918, although there had once been Turkish baths on the site, and in the Middle Ages a hospital. In 1927, the Baths were extended to include the wave pool, and the effervescent bath was added in 1934. The well-preserved Art Nouveau interior includes colourful mosaics, marble columns, stained glass windows and statues.

The [Lukács Baths](/wiki/Luk%C3%A1cs_Baths "Lukács Baths") are also in Buda and are also Turkish in origin, although they were only revived at the end of the 19th century. This was also when the spa and treatment centre were founded. There is still something of an atmosphere of fin-de-siècle about the place, and all around the inner courtyard there are marble tablets recalling the thanks of patrons who were cured there. Since the 1950s it has been regarded as a centre for intellectuals and artists.

The [Széchenyi Baths](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Baths "Széchenyi Baths") are one of the largest bathing complexes in all Europe, and the only "old" medicinal baths to be found in the Pest side of the city. The indoor medicinal baths date from 1913 and the outdoor pools from 1927. There is an atmosphere of grandeur about the whole place with the bright, largest pools resembling aspects associated with Roman baths, the smaller bath tubs reminding one of the bathing culture of the Greeks, and the saunas and diving pools borrowed from traditions emanating in northern Europe. The three outdoor pools (one of which is a fun pool) are open all year, including winter. Indoors there are over ten separate pools, and a whole host of medical treatments is also available. The Szécheny Baths are built in modern Renaissance style.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Budapest%2C_Bajcsy-Zsilinszki_%C3%BAt%2C_panor%C3%A1ma%2C_2.jpg/1300px-Budapest%2C_Bajcsy-Zsilinszki_%C3%BAt%2C_panor%C3%A1ma%2C_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Budapest,_Bajcsy-Zsilinszki_%C3%BAt,_panor%C3%A1ma,_2.jpg "Panorama of Budapest with Gellért Hill, Liberty Statue, Budapest Eye, Buda Castle, Matthias Church, Parliament, St. Stephen's Basilica")  
[](/wiki/File:Budapest,_Bajcsy-Zsilinszki_%C3%BAt,_panor%C3%A1ma,_2.jpg "File:Budapest, Bajcsy-Zsilinszki út, panoráma, 2.jpg")
Panorama of Budapest with [Gellért Hill](/wiki/Gell%C3%A9rt_Hill "Gellért Hill"), [Liberty Statue](/wiki/Liberty_Statue_(Budapest) "Liberty Statue (Budapest)"), Budapest Eye, [Buda Castle](/wiki/Buda_Castle "Buda Castle"), [Matthias Church](/wiki/Matthias_Church "Matthias Church"), [Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building "Hungarian Parliament Building"), [St. Stephen's Basilica](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Basilica "St. Stephen's Basilica")  

Infrastructure and transportation {#Infrastructure_and_transportation}
----------------------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Infrastructure and transportation")\]  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Airport")\]  
Main article: [Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport](/wiki/Budapest_Ferenc_Liszt_International_Airport "Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Liszt_Ferenc_Repuloter_2-es_terminal_varocsarnok_06.JPG/220px-Liszt_Ferenc_Repuloter_2-es_terminal_varocsarnok_06.JPG)](/wiki/File:Liszt_Ferenc_Repuloter_2-es_terminal_varocsarnok_06.JPG) [Budapest International Airport](/wiki/Budapest_Ferenc_Liszt_International_Airport "Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport") arrivals and departures lounge between [terminal](/wiki/Airport_terminal "Airport terminal") 2A and 2B, named SkyCourt

Budapest is served by [Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport](/wiki/Budapest_Ferenc_Liszt_International_Airport "Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport") (BUD) (named after [Franz Liszt](/wiki/Franz_Liszt "Franz Liszt"), the notable Hungarian composer), one of the busiest airports in [Central and Eastern Europe](/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe "Central and Eastern Europe"), located 16 kilometres (9.9 mi) east-southeast of the centre of Budapest, in the [District XVIII](/wiki/Pestszentl%C5%91rinc-Pestszentimre "Pestszentlőrinc-Pestszentimre"). The airport offers international connections among all major European cities, and also to North America, Africa, Asia and the Middle East. As Hungary's busiest airport, it handles nearly all of the country's air passenger traffic. Budapest Liszt Ferenc handled around 250 [scheduled flights](/wiki/Airline "Airline") daily in 2013, and an ever-rising number of [charters](/wiki/Air_charter "Air charter"). London, [Brussels](/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), Frankfurt, [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"), Paris, and [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam") are the busiest international connections respectively, while [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"), Montreal, [Dubai](/wiki/Dubai "Dubai"), [Doha](/wiki/Doha "Doha") and [Alicante](/wiki/Alicante "Alicante") are the most unusual in the region.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-201)^ Today the airport serves as a base for [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair"), [Wizz Air](/wiki/Wizz_Air "Wizz Air"), [Budapest Aircraft Service](/wiki/Budapest_Aircraft_Service "Budapest Aircraft Service"), [LOT Polish Airlines](/wiki/LOT_Polish_Airlines "LOT Polish Airlines") and [Smartwings Hungary](/wiki/Travel_Service_Hungary "Travel Service Hungary") among others. The airport is accessible via public transportation from the city centre by the Metro line 3 and then the airport bus [200E](/wiki/Budapest_bus_route_200E "Budapest bus route 200E") and [100E](/wiki/Budapest_bus_route_100E "Budapest bus route 100E").^[\[201\]](#cite_note-202)^{#cite_ref-202}

As part of a strategic development plan, €561 million have been spent on expanding and modernising the [airport infrastructure](/wiki/Airport_infrastructure "Airport infrastructure") until December 2012. Most of these improvements are already completed,^[\[202\]](#cite_note-203)^ the postponed ones are the new cargo area and new piers for terminal 2A and 2B, but these development are on standby also, and will start immediately, when the airport traffic will reach the appropriate level. SkyCourt, the newest, state-of-the-art building between the 2A and 2B terminals with 5 levels. Passenger safety checks were moved here along with new baggage classifiers and the new Malév and SkyTeam [business lounges](/wiki/Airport_lounge "Airport lounge"), as well as the first MasterCard lounge in Europe.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-204)^{#cite_ref-204}  

### Public transportation {#Public_transportation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Public transportation")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Budapest_metro_hev_en.png/220px-Budapest_metro_hev_en.png)](/wiki/File:Budapest_metro_hev_en.png) Budapest [metro and rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") network within the city and to suburbs [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Metro_4%2C_M4%2C_Line_4_%28Budapest_Metro%29%2C_K%C3%A1lvin_t%C3%A9r.jpg/220px-Metro_4%2C_M4%2C_Line_4_%28Budapest_Metro%29%2C_K%C3%A1lvin_t%C3%A9r.jpg)](/wiki/File:Metro_4,_M4,_Line_4_(Budapest_Metro),_K%C3%A1lvin_t%C3%A9r.jpg) [Green Line 4](/wiki/Line_4_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 4 (Budapest Metro)"), a [driverless metro](/wiki/Automatic_train_operation "Automatic train operation") line with real-time [PIDS](/wiki/Passenger_information_system "Passenger information system") system at Kálvin square, a transfer station to [Blue Line 3](/wiki/Line_3_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 3 (Budapest Metro)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/17-es_villamos_%282211%29.jpg/220px-17-es_villamos_%282211%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:17-es_villamos_(2211).jpg) CAF Tram on Line 17 at Széll Kálmán Square

Public transit in Budapest is provided by the [Centre for Budapest Transport (BKK, *Budapesti Közlekedési Központ*)](/wiki/Budapesti_K%C3%B6zleked%C3%A9si_K%C3%B6zpont "Budapesti Közlekedési Központ"), one of the largest [transportation authorities](/wiki/Transportation_authority "Transportation authority") in Europe.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-205)^ BKK operates 4 [metro lines](/wiki/Budapest_Metro "Budapest Metro") (including the historic [Line 1](/wiki/Line_1_(Budapest_Metro) "Line 1 (Budapest Metro)"), the oldest underground railway in continental Europe), 5 [suburban railway lines](/wiki/H%C3%89V "HÉV"), 33 [tram lines](/wiki/Trams_in_Budapest "Trams in Budapest"), 15 trolleybus lines, 264 bus lines (including 40 [night routes](/wiki/Night_bus "Night bus")), 4 boat services, and *[BuBi](/wiki/BuBi "BuBi")* , a smart [bicycle sharing network](/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system "Bicycle sharing system"). On an average weekday, BKK lines transports 3.9 million riders; in 2011, it handled a total of 1.4 billion passengers.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-206)^ In 2014, the 65% of the passenger traffic in Budapest was by public transport and 35% by car. The aim is 80%--20% by 2030 in accordance with the strategy of BKK.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-207)^{#cite_ref-207}

People aged 65 and over and under 14 travel free.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-208)^{#cite_ref-208}

The development of complex [intelligent transportation system](/wiki/Intelligent_transportation_system "Intelligent transportation system") in the city is advancing; the application of [smart traffic lights](/wiki/Smart_traffic_light "Smart traffic light") is widespread, they are GPS and computer controlled and give priority to the GPS connected public transport vehicles automatically, as well as the traffic is measured and analyzed on the roads and car drivers informed about the expected travel time and traffic by intelligent displays (EasyWay project).^[\[208\]](#cite_note-209)^ Public transport users are immediately notified of any changes in public transport online, on [smartphones](/wiki/Smartphones "Smartphones") and on [PIDS](/wiki/Passenger_information_system "Passenger information system") displays, as well car drivers can keep track of changes in traffic and road management in real-time online and on [smartphones](/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone") through the *BKK Info* .^[\[209\]](#cite_note-210)^^[\[210\]](#cite_note-211)^ As well all vehicles can be followed online and on smartphones in real-time throughout the city with the *Futár* PIDS system,^[\[211\]](#cite_note-212)^ while the continuous introducing of [integrated e-ticket](/wiki/Integrated_ticketing "Integrated ticketing") system will help the measurement of passenger numbers on each line and the intelligent control of service frequency.{#cite_ref-212}

The development of *Futár* , the citywide [real-time](/wiki/Real-time_business_intelligence "Real-time business intelligence") [passenger information system](/wiki/Passenger_information_system "Passenger information system") and real-time [route planner](/wiki/Public_transport_route_planner "Public transport route planner") is finished already and now all of the public transport vehicle is connected via satellite system. The real-time information of trams, buses and trolleybuses are available for both the operators in the control room and for all the passengers in all stops on smartphone and on city street displays.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-213)^ The implementation of latest generation [automated fare collection](/wiki/Automated_fare_collection_system "Automated fare collection system") and [e-ticket system](/wiki/Electronic_ticket "Electronic ticket") with [NFC](/wiki/Near_field_communication "Near field communication") compatibility and reusable [contactless](/wiki/Contactless_payment "Contactless payment") [smart cards](/wiki/Smart_card "Smart card") for making [electronic payments](/wiki/Electronic_money "Electronic money") in online and offline systems in Budapest is started in 2014, the project is implemented and operated by the operator of Hong Kong [Octopus card](/wiki/Octopus_card "Octopus card") jointly with one of the leading European companies of e-ticket and automated fare collection, [Scheidt \& Bachmann](/wiki/Scheidt_%26_Bachmann_Ticket_XPress "Scheidt & Bachmann Ticket XPress").^[\[213\]](#cite_note-214)^ The deployment of 300 new digital contactless [ticket vending machine](/wiki/Ticket_vending_machine "Ticket vending machine") will be finished by the end of 2014 in harmonization with the e-ticket system.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-215)^ In 2022, *Futár* was rebranded as *BudapestGo.* ^[\[215\]](#cite_note-216)^{#cite_ref-216}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/5-%C3%B6s_busz_%28MYK-372%29.jpg/220px-5-%C3%B6s_busz_%28MYK-372%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:5-%C3%B6s_busz_(MYK-372).jpg) A Volvo 7900A Hybrid in Budapest on Line 5 operated by BKK

Tram lines no. 4 and 6 are the busiest city tram lines in the world,^[\[216\]](#cite_note-217)^ with one of the world's longest trams (54-metre long Siemens [Combino](/wiki/Combino "Combino")) running at 2--3-minute intervals at peak time and 4--5 minutes off-peak. Day services are usually from 4 am until between 11 pm and 0:30 am.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-A_good_place_to_live_–_Budapest-182)^ [Hungarian State Railways](/wiki/Hungarian_State_Railways "Hungarian State Railways") operates an extensive network of [commuter rail](/wiki/Commuter_rail "Commuter rail") services, their importance in the suburban commuter passenger traffic is significant, but in travel within the city is limited. The organiser of public transport in Budapest is the [municipal corporation](/wiki/Municipal_corporation "Municipal corporation") *Centre for Budapest Transport* (Budapesti Közlekedési Központ -- BKK), that is responsible for planning and organising network and services, planning and developing tariff concepts, attending to [public service](/wiki/Public_service "Public service") procurer duties, managing public service contracts, operating controlling and monitoring systems, setting and monitoring service level agreements related to public transport, attending to customer service duties, selling and monitoring tickets and passes, attending to integrated passenger information duties, unified Budapest-centric traffic control within public transport, attending to duties related to river navigation, plus the management of Budapest roads, operating [taxi stations](/wiki/Taxi_station "Taxi station"), unified control of [bicycle traffic](/wiki/Bicycle_traffic "Bicycle traffic") development in the capital, preparing [parking](/wiki/Parking "Parking") strategy and developing an operational concept, preparation of road traffic management, developing an optimal [traffic management](/wiki/Traffic_management "Traffic management") system, organising and co-ordinating road reconstruction and more, in short, everything which is related to transport in the city.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-218)^{#cite_ref-218}  

### Roads and railways {#Roads_and_railways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Roads and railways")\]  
Main articles: [Hungarian State Railways](/wiki/Hungarian_State_Railways "Hungarian State Railways") and [Motorways in Hungary](/wiki/Motorways_in_Hungary "Motorways in Hungary")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Nyugati_p%C3%A1lyaudvar%2C_Budapest.jpg/220px-Nyugati_p%C3%A1lyaudvar%2C_Budapest.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nyugati_p%C3%A1lyaudvar,_Budapest.jpg) [Western railway station](/wiki/Budapest_Nyugati_station "Budapest Nyugati station") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Civertanmegyeri5.jpg/220px-Civertanmegyeri5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Civertanmegyeri5.jpg) [Megyeri Bridge](/wiki/Megyeri_Bridge "Megyeri Bridge") on [M0 highway ring road](/wiki/M0_motorway_(Hungary) "M0 motorway (Hungary)") around Budapest [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/14-05-06-budapest-RalfR-11.jpg/220px-14-05-06-budapest-RalfR-11.jpg)](/wiki/File:14-05-06-budapest-RalfR-11.jpg) [Keleti Railway Station](/wiki/Budapest_Keleti_railway_station "Budapest Keleti railway station") (Budapest East Central)

Budapest is the most important Hungarian road terminus, all of the major highways and railways end within the city limits. The road system in the city is designed in a similar manner to that of Paris, with several ring roads, and avenues radiating out from the center. [Ring road](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road") [M0](/wiki/M0_motorway_(Hungary) "M0 motorway (Hungary)") around Budapest is nearly completed, with only one section missing on the west side due to local disputes. The ring road is 80 kilometres (50 miles) in length, and once finished it will be 107 kilometres (66 mi) of highway in length.

The city is a vital traffic hub because all major European roads and European railway lines lead to Budapest.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-budapest.com-90)^ The Danube was and is still today an important water-way and this region in the centre of the Carpathian Basin lies at the cross-roads of trade routes.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-budpocketguide.com-93)^ Hungarian main line railways are operated by Hungarian State Railways. There are three main railway station in Budapest, [Keleti (*Eastern*)](/wiki/Budapest_Keleti_p%C3%A1lyaudvar "Budapest Keleti pályaudvar"), [Nyugati (*Western*)](/wiki/Budapest_Nyugati_p%C3%A1lyaudvar "Budapest Nyugati pályaudvar") and [Déli (*Southern*)](/wiki/Budapest_D%C3%A9li_p%C3%A1lyaudvar "Budapest Déli pályaudvar"), operating both domestic and international [rail services](/wiki/Rail_service "Rail service"). Budapest is one of the main stops of the Orient Express on its Central and Eastern European route.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-219)^ There is also a [suburban rail](/wiki/Suburban_trains_in_Budapest "Suburban trains in Budapest") service in and around Budapest, three lines of which are operated under the name HÉV.{#cite_ref-219}  

### Ports, shipping and others {#Ports.2C_shipping_and_others}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Ports, shipping and others")\]

The river Danube flows through Budapest on its way from (Germany) to the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea"). The river is easily navigable and so Budapest historically has a major [commercial port](/wiki/Commercial_port "Commercial port") at [Csepel](/wiki/Csepel "Csepel") District and at [New Pest](/wiki/%C3%9Ajpest "Újpest") District also. The Pest side is also a famous port place with [international shipping](/wiki/International_shipping "International shipping") ports for cargo^[\[219\]](#cite_note-220)^ and for passenger ships.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-221)^ In the summer months, a scheduled [hydrofoil](/wiki/Hydrofoil "Hydrofoil") service operates on the Danube connecting the city to Vienna.{#cite_ref-221}

BKK (through the operator [BKV](/wiki/Budapesti_K%C3%B6zleked%C3%A9si_Zrt. "Budapesti Közlekedési Zrt.")) also provides public transport with boat service within the borders of the city. Two routes, marked D11 and D12, connect the two banks with Margaret Island and Óbuda Island, from Rómaifürdő (Buda side, north to Óbuda Island) or Árpád Bridge (Pest side) to Rákóczi Bridge, with a total of 18 stops, while route D2 circulates in the downtown.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-bkk-boats-222)^ Line D14 is a ferry service, connecting Királyerdő on the [Csepel Island](/wiki/Csepel_Island "Csepel Island") with Molnár Island on the Pest side, south to the city centre.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-bkk-boats-222)^ In addition, several companies provides sightseeing boat trips and also an amphibious vehicle (bus and boat) operates constantly.{#cite_ref-bkk-boats_222-1}

Water quality in Budapest harbours improved dramatically in the recent years, treatment facilities processed 100% of generated sewage in 2010. Budapesters regularly [kayak](/wiki/Kayak "Kayak"), [canoe](/wiki/Canoe "Canoe"), [jet-ski](/wiki/Jet-ski "Jet-ski") and [sail](/wiki/Sail "Sail") on the Danube, which has continuously become a major recreational site for the city.

Special vehicles in Budapest, besides metros, include suburban rails, trams and boats. There are a couple of less common vehicles in Budapest, like the trolleybus on several lines in [Pest](/wiki/Pest_(city) "Pest (city)"), the [Castle Hill Funicular](/wiki/Budapest_Castle_Hill_Funicular "Budapest Castle Hill Funicular") between the [Chain Bridge](/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge "Széchenyi Chain Bridge") and Buda Castle, the [cyclecar](/wiki/Cyclecar "Cyclecar") for rent in Margaret Island, the [chairlift](/wiki/Chairlift "Chairlift"), the [Budapest Cog-wheel Railway](/wiki/Budapest_Cog-wheel_Railway "Budapest Cog-wheel Railway") and [children's railway](/wiki/Children%27s_railway "Children's railway"). The latter three vehicles run among Buda hills.  

Culture and contemporary life {#Culture_and_contemporary_life}
--------------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Culture and contemporary life")\]  
Main pages: [Category:Culture in Budapest](/wiki/Category:Culture_in_Budapest "Category:Culture in Budapest") and [Culture of Hungary](/wiki/Culture_of_Hungary "Culture of Hungary")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences_IMG_1055.jpg/220px-Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences_IMG_1055.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences_IMG_1055.jpg) [Hungarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Hungarian Academy of Sciences") seat in Budapest, founded in 1825 by [Count István Széchenyi](/wiki/Istv%C3%A1n_Sz%C3%A9chenyi "István Széchenyi")

The culture of Budapest is reflected by Budapest's size and variety. Most Hungarian cultural movements first emerged in the city. Budapest is an important center for music, film, theatre, dance and visual art. Artists have been drawn into the city by opportunity, as the city government funds the arts with adequate financial resources. Budapest is the headquarters of the Hungarian [LGBT](/wiki/LGBT "LGBT") community\[Citation needed\].

Budapest was named "City of Design" in December 2015 and has been a member of [UNESCO Creative Cities Network](/wiki/Creative_Cities_Network "Creative Cities Network") since then.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}  

### Museums and galleries {#Museums_and_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Museums and galleries")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Budapest_Fine_Arts_Museum_bldg.jpg/183px-Budapest_Fine_Arts_Museum_bldg.jpg)](/wiki/File:Budapest_Fine_Arts_Museum_bldg.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Museum_of_Applied_Arts_%28Budapest%29.jpg/181px-Museum_of_Applied_Arts_%28Budapest%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museum_of_Applied_Arts_(Budapest).jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/F%C3%B6ldtani_int%C3%A9zet_-_Budapest.jpg/182px-F%C3%B6ldtani_int%C3%A9zet_-_Budapest.jpg)](/wiki/File:F%C3%B6ldtani_int%C3%A9zet_-_Budapest.jpg)

**Clockwise, from upper left** : [Museum of Fine Arts Budapest](/wiki/Museum_of_Fine_Arts_(Budapest) "Museum of Fine Arts (Budapest)"); [Museum of Applied Arts](/wiki/Museum_of_Applied_Arts_(Budapest) "Museum of Applied Arts (Budapest)"); a view of the interior of the [Aquincum Museum](/wiki/Aquincum_Museum "Aquincum Museum"); and [Geological Museum of Budapest](/wiki/Geological_Museum_of_Budapest "Geological Museum of Budapest")

Budapest is packed with museums and galleries. The city glories in 223 museums and galleries, which presents several memories, next to the Hungarian ones as well those of universal and European culture and science. Here are the greatest examples among them: the [Hungarian National Museum](/wiki/Hungarian_National_Museum "Hungarian National Museum"), the [Hungarian National Gallery](/wiki/Hungarian_National_Gallery "Hungarian National Gallery"), the Museum of Fine Arts (where can see the pictures of Hungarian painters, like [Victor Vasarely](/wiki/Victor_Vasarely "Victor Vasarely"), [Mihály Munkácsy](/wiki/Mih%C3%A1ly_Munk%C3%A1csy "Mihály Munkácsy") and a great collection about [Italian art](/wiki/Italian_art "Italian art"), [Dutch art](/wiki/Dutch_art "Dutch art"), [Spanish art](/wiki/Spanish_art "Spanish art") and [British art](/wiki/British_art "British art") from before the 19th century and [French art](/wiki/French_art "French art"), British art, [German art](/wiki/German_art "German art"), [Austrian art](/wiki/Austrian_art "Austrian art") after the 19th century), the House of Terror, the Budapest Historical Museum, the Aquincum Museum, the [Semmelweis Museum of Medical History](/wiki/Semmelweis_Museum_of_Medical_History "Semmelweis Museum of Medical History"), the Memento Park, [Museum of Applied Arts](/wiki/Museum_of_Applied_Arts_(Budapest) "Museum of Applied Arts (Budapest)") and the contemporary arts exhibition Palace of Arts Budapest.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-224)^ In Budapest there are 837 monuments, which represent most of the European artistic styles. The classical and unique [Hungarian Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") buildings are prominent.{#cite_ref-224}  

### Libraries {#Libraries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Libraries")\]

Many libraries have unique collections in Budapest, such as the National Széchényi Library, which keeps historical relics from the age before the printing of books. The [Metropolitan Szabó Ervin Library](/wiki/Metropolitan_Szab%C3%B3_Ervin_Library "Metropolitan Szabó Ervin Library") plays an important role in the general education of the capital's population. Other libraries: The Library of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Eötvös University Library, the Parliamentary Library, Library of the Hungarian Central Statistical Office and the National Library of Foreign Literature.  

### Opera and theatres {#Opera_and_theatres}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Opera and theatres")\]  
Main article: [Hungarian opera](/wiki/Hungarian_opera "Hungarian opera")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/%C3%92pera_de_Budapest.jpg/220px-%C3%92pera_de_Budapest.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C3%92pera_de_Budapest.jpg) [Hungarian State Opera House](/wiki/Hungarian_State_Opera_House "Hungarian State Opera House")

In Budapest there are forty theatres, seven concert halls and an opera house.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-225)^ Outdoor festivals, concerts and lectures enrich the cultural offer of summer, which are often held in historical buildings. The largest theatre facilities are the Budapest Operetta and Musical Theatre, the József Attila Theatre, the Katona József Theatre, the Madách Theatre, the Hungarian State Opera House, the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Budapest) "National Theatre (Budapest)"), the Vigadó Concert Hall, Radnóti Miklós Theatre, the [Comedy Theatre](/wiki/Comedy_Theatre_of_Budapest "Comedy Theatre of Budapest") and the Palace of Arts, known as *MUPA* . The [Budapest Opera Ball](/wiki/Budapest_Opera_Ball "Budapest Opera Ball") is an annual Hungarian [society](/wiki/Upper_class "Upper class") event taking place in the building of the [Budapest Opera](/wiki/Budapest_Opera "Budapest Opera") (*Operaház* ) on the last Saturday of the carnival season, usually late February.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-226)^{#cite_ref-226}  

### Casinos {#Casinos}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Casinos")\]

There are 11 casinos in Hungary (11 is the maximum number of casinos allowed by law), and five of them are located in the capital. All five of these casinos were owned by LVC Diamond Játékkaszinó Üzemeltető Kft, the gambling company of late [András Vajna](/wiki/Andrew_G._Vajna "Andrew G. Vajna") (better known as Andy Vajna) until his death in 2017. The biggest casino in Budapest and in all of Hungary is the Las Vegas Casino at the Corvin promenade.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-227)^{#cite_ref-227}  

### Performing arts and festivals {#Performing_arts_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Performing arts and festivals")\]  
Further information: [Music of Budapest](/wiki/Music_of_Budapest "Music of Budapest")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Sziget_Magyar_Dal.jpg/220px-Sziget_Magyar_Dal.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sziget_Magyar_Dal.jpg) [Sziget Festival](/wiki/Sziget_Festival "Sziget Festival") Budapest. One of the largest music festivals in Europe provides a multicultural, diverse meeting point for locals and foreigners every year.

Several annual festivals take place in Budapest. The [Sziget Festival](/wiki/Sziget_Festival "Sziget Festival") is one of the largest outdoor music festival in Europe. The [Budapest Spring Festival](/wiki/Budapest_Spring_Festival "Budapest Spring Festival") includes concerts at several venues across the city. The [Café Budapest Contemporary Arts Festival](/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Budapest_Contemporary_Arts_Festival "Café Budapest Contemporary Arts Festival") (formerly the Budapest Autumn Festival) brings free music, dance, art, and other cultural events to the streets of the city. The Budapest Wine Festival and Budapest [Pálinka](/wiki/P%C3%A1linka "Pálinka") Festival, occurring each May, are [gastronomy](/wiki/Gastronomy "Gastronomy") festivals focusing on culinary pleasures. The [Budapest Pride](/wiki/Budapest_Pride "Budapest Pride") (or Budapest Pride Film and Cultural Festival) occurs annually across the city, and usually involves a parade on the Andrássy Avenue. Other festivals include the [Budapest Fringe Festival](/wiki/Budapest_Fringe_Festival "Budapest Fringe Festival"), which brings more than 500 artists in about 50 shows to produce a wide range of works in [alternative theatre](/wiki/Alternative_theatre "Alternative theatre"), dance, music and comedy outside the mainstream. The [LOW Festival](/wiki/LOW_Festival "LOW Festival") is a contemporary cultural festival held in Hungary in the cities Budapest and Pécs from February until March; the name of the festival alludes to the [Low Countries](/wiki/Low_Countries "Low Countries"), the region encompassing the Netherlands and Flanders. The Budapest Jewish Summer Festival, in late August, is one of the largest in Europe.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Fireworks_in_St._Stephen%27s_Day.png/220px-Fireworks_in_St._Stephen%27s_Day.png)](/wiki/File:Fireworks_in_St._Stephen%27s_Day.png) Festive fireworks of the [foundation of the Hungarian state](/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Hungary "Public holidays in Hungary") on 20 August

There are many symphony orchestras in Budapest, with the [Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Budapest_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra") being the preeminent one. It was founded in 1853 by [Ferenc Erkel](/wiki/Ferenc_Erkel "Ferenc Erkel") and still presents regular concerts in the Hungarian State Opera House and [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Budapest) "National Theatre (Budapest)"). Budapest also has one of the more active jazz scenes in Central Europe.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-228)^{#cite_ref-228}

The dance tradition of the Carpathian Basin is a unique area of the European dance culture, which is also a special transition between the Balkans and Western Europe regions. The city is home to several authentic [Hungarian folk dance ensembles](/wiki/Music_of_Budapest "Music of Budapest") which range from small ensembles to professional troupes. Budapest is one of the few cities in the world with a high school for learning folk dance.  

### Fashion {#Fashion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Fashion")\]

Budapest is home to a [fashion week](/wiki/Fashion_week "Fashion week") twice a year, where the city's fashion designers and houses present their collections and provide a meeting place for the [fashion industry](/wiki/Fashion_industry "Fashion industry") representatives. [Budapest Fashion Week](/wiki/Budapest_Fashion_Week "Budapest Fashion Week") additionally a place for designers from other countries may present their collections in Budapest. Hungarian models, like [Barbara Palvin](/wiki/Barbara_Palvin "Barbara Palvin"), [Enikő Mihalik](/wiki/Enik%C5%91_Mihalik "Enikő Mihalik"), Diána Mészáros, [Viktória Vámosi](/wiki/Vikt%C3%B3ria_V%C3%A1mosi "Viktória Vámosi") usually appearing at these events along international participants. Fashion brands like [Zara](/wiki/Zara_(clothing) "Zara (clothing)"), [H\&M](/wiki/H%26M "H&M"), [Mango](/wiki/Mango_(clothing) "Mango (clothing)"), [ESPRIT](/wiki/Esprit_Holdings "Esprit Holdings"), [Douglas AG](/wiki/Douglas_AG "Douglas AG"), [Lacoste](/wiki/Lacoste "Lacoste"), [Tommy Hilfiger](/wiki/Tommy_Hilfiger_(company) "Tommy Hilfiger (company)"), [Guess](/wiki/Guess_(company) "Guess (company)"), [Nike](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc.") and other retail fashion brands are common across the city's shopping malls and on the streets.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-229)^{#cite_ref-229}

Major luxury fashion brands such as [Louis Vuitton](/wiki/Louis_Vuitton "Louis Vuitton"), [Burberry](/wiki/Burberry "Burberry"), [Furla](/wiki/Furla "Furla"), [Gucci](/wiki/Gucci "Gucci"), [Versace](/wiki/Versace "Versace"), [Zegna](/wiki/Zegna "Zegna"), [Max Mara](/wiki/Max_Mara "Max Mara"), [Michael Kors](/wiki/Michael_Kors "Michael Kors"), [Karl Lagerfeld](/wiki/Karl_Lagerfeld "Karl Lagerfeld") and [Hugo Boss](/wiki/Hugo_Boss "Hugo Boss"), or luxury watch brands such as [Rolex](/wiki/Rolex "Rolex"), [Hublot](/wiki/Hublot "Hublot"), [Omega](/wiki/Omega_SA "Omega SA"), [Breitling](/wiki/Breitling_SA "Breitling SA"), [Tissot](/wiki/Tissot "Tissot") and [TAG Heuer](/wiki/TAG_Heuer "TAG Heuer"), can be found among the city's most prestigious shopping streets, the Fashion Street, [Váci Street](/wiki/V%C3%A1ci_Street "Váci Street") and Andrássy Avenue in Budapest's main upscale fashion district, the Leopoldtown.  

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Media")\]

Budapest is a prominent location for the Hungarian entertainment industry, with many films, television series, books, and other media set there. Budapest is the largest centre for film and television production in Hungary. In 2011, it employed more than 50,000 people and generated 63.9% of revenues of the media industry in the country.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-230)^ Budapest is the media centre of Hungary, and the location of the main headquarters of [Hungarian Television](/wiki/Magyar_Telev%C3%ADzi%C3%B3 "Magyar Televízió") and other local and national TV and radio stations, such as [M1](/wiki/M1_(TV_channel) "M1 (TV channel)"), [M2](/wiki/M2_(TV_channel) "M2 (TV channel)"), [Duna TV](/wiki/Duna_TV "Duna TV"), Duna World, [RTL Klub](/wiki/RTL_Klub "RTL Klub"), [TV2 (Hungary)](/wiki/TV2_(Hungary) "TV2 (Hungary)"), [Euronews](/wiki/Euronews "Euronews"), [Comedy Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central_Hungary "Comedy Central Hungary"), [MTV Hungary](/wiki/MTV_Hungary "MTV Hungary"), [VIVA Hungary](/wiki/Viva_(TV_station)#VIVA_Hungary "Viva (TV station)"), [Viasat 3](/wiki/Viasat_3 "Viasat 3"), [Cool TV](/wiki/Cool_TV "Cool TV"), and Pro4, and politics and news channels such as [Hír TV](/wiki/H%C3%ADr_TV "Hír TV"), [ATV](/wiki/ATV_(Hungary) "ATV (Hungary)"), and [Echo TV](/wiki/Echo_TV "Echo TV"). Documentary channels include [Discovery Channel](/wiki/Discovery_Channel_Hungary "Discovery Channel Hungary"), [Discovery Science](/wiki/Discovery_Science_Europe/ME "Discovery Science Europe/ME"), [Discovery World](/wiki/Discovery_World_(TV_channel) "Discovery World (TV channel)"), [National Geographic Channel](/wiki/National_Geographic_Channel "National Geographic Channel"), [Nat Geo Wild](/wiki/Nat_Geo_Wild "Nat Geo Wild"), Spektrum TV, and [BBC Entertainment](/wiki/BBC_Entertainment "BBC Entertainment"). This is less than a quarter of the channels broadcast from Budapest; for the whole picture see [Television in Hungary](/wiki/Television_in_Hungary "Television in Hungary").{#cite_ref-230}

In 2012, in Hungary there were 7.2 million [internet users](/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_by_number_of_Internet_users "List of sovereign states by number of Internet users") (72% of the population)^[\[230\]](#cite_note-NIUCalc-231)^ and 2.3 million subscriptions for mobile broadband.^[\[231\]](#cite_note-MobleBroadbandITUDynamic2012-232)^{#cite_ref-MobleBroadbandITUDynamic2012_232-0}  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]  
Further information: [Hungarian cuisine](/wiki/Hungarian_cuisine "Hungarian cuisine")

In the modern age, Budapest developed its own peculiar cuisine, based on products of the nearby region, such as lamb, pork and vegetables special to the region. Modern Hungarian cuisine is a synthesis of ancient Asiatic components mixed with French, Germanic, Italian, and Slavic elements. The food of Hungary can be considered a melting pot of the continent, with a culinary base formed from its own, original [Magyar](/wiki/Magyar_tribes "Magyar tribes") cuisine. Considerable numbers of [Saxons](/wiki/Saxons "Saxons"), Armenians, Italians, Jews and Serbs settled in the Hungarian basin and in Transylvania, also contributing with different new dishes. Elements of ancient Turkish cuisine were adopted during the Ottoman era, in the form of sweets (for example different [nougats](/wiki/Nougat "Nougat"), like white nougat called *törökméz* ), [quince](/wiki/Quince "Quince") (*birsalma* ), [Turkish delight](/wiki/Turkish_delight "Turkish delight"), [Turkish coffee](/wiki/Turkish_coffee "Turkish coffee") or rice dishes like [pilaf](/wiki/Pilaf "Pilaf"), meat and vegetable dishes like the [eggplant](/wiki/Eggplant "Eggplant"), used in [eggplant salads and appetizers](/wiki/Eggplant_salads_and_appetizers "Eggplant salads and appetizers"), stuffed peppers and stuffed cabbage called *[töltött káposzta](/wiki/T%C3%B6lt%C3%B6tt_k%C3%A1poszta "Töltött káposzta")* . Hungarian cuisine was influenced by [Austrian cuisine](/wiki/Austrian_cuisine "Austrian cuisine") under the [Austro-Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire "Austro-Hungarian Empire"), dishes and methods of food preparation have often been borrowed from Austrian cuisine, and vice versa.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-233)^{#cite_ref-233}

Budapest restaurants reflect diversity, with menus carrying traditional regional cuisine, fusions of various culinary influences, or innovating in the leading edge of new techniques. Budapest' food shops also have a solid reputation for supplying quality specialised culinary products and supplies, reputations that are often built up over generations. These include many shop and served in several [Michelin-starred](/wiki/List_of_Michelin_starred_restaurants#By_country "List of Michelin starred restaurants") restaurants.
