Some of the better known feature films set in Budapest are *[Kontroll](/wiki/Kontroll "Kontroll")* , *[The District!](/wiki/The_District! "The District!")* , *[Gloomy Sunday](/wiki/Ein_Lied_von_Liebe_und_Tod "Ein Lied von Liebe und Tod")* , *[Sunshine](/wiki/Sunshine_(1999_film) "Sunshine (1999 film)")* , *[An American Rhapsody](/wiki/An_American_Rhapsody "An American Rhapsody")* , *[As You Desire Me](/wiki/As_You_Desire_Me_(film) "As You Desire Me (film)")* , *[The Good Fairy](/wiki/The_Good_Fairy_(1935_film) "The Good Fairy (1935 film)")* , *[Hanna's War](/wiki/Hanna%27s_War "Hanna's War")* , *[The Journey](/wiki/The_Journey_(1959_film) "The Journey (1959 film)")* , *[Ladies in Love](/wiki/Ladies_in_Love "Ladies in Love")* , *[Music Box](/wiki/Music_Box_(film) "Music Box (film)")* , *[The Shop Around the Corner](/wiki/The_Shop_Around_the_Corner "The Shop Around the Corner")* , *[Zoo in Budapest](/wiki/Zoo_in_Budapest "Zoo in Budapest")* , *[Underworld](/wiki/Underworld_(2003_film) "Underworld (2003 film)")* , *[Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol](/wiki/Mission:_Impossible_%E2%80%93_Ghost_Protocol "Mission: Impossible – Ghost Protocol")* and Spy. Budapest, Hungary's capital, has long been a favorite destination for Hollywood filmmakers, drawn to its enchanting ambiance, timeless charm, and breathtaking landmarks.Budapest has also served as a muse for some of the most distinctive directors and films such as Love and Death, Evita, [The Phantom of the Opera](/wiki/The_Phantom_of_the_Opera_(novel) "The Phantom of the Opera (novel)"), Blade Runner 2049, [The Martian](/wiki/The_Martian_(film) "The Martian (film)"), Spy, [Atomic Blonde](/wiki/Atomic_Blonde "Atomic Blonde"), [Red Sparrow](/wiki/Red_Sparrow "Red Sparrow"), [A Good Day to Die Hard](/wiki/A_Good_Day_to_Die_Hard "A Good Day to Die Hard").^[\[233\]](#cite_note-234)^ *[The Grand Budapest Hotel](/wiki/The_Grand_Budapest_Hotel "The Grand Budapest Hotel")* (2014) is a Wes Anderson film. It was filmed in Germany, and set in the fictional Republic of Zubrowka, which is in the alpine mountains of Hungary.{#cite_ref-234}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
See also: [Category:Sport in Budapest](/wiki/Category:Sport_in_Budapest "Category:Sport in Budapest") and [Football in Hungary](/wiki/Football_in_Hungary "Football in Hungary")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Pusk%C3%A1s_Ar%C3%A9na_02.jpg/220px-Pusk%C3%A1s_Ar%C3%A9na_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pusk%C3%A1s_Ar%C3%A9na_02.jpg) [Puskás Aréna](/wiki/Pusk%C3%A1s_Ar%C3%A9na "Puskás Aréna") National Stadium and [László Papp Arena](/wiki/L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_Papp_Budapest_Sports_Arena "László Papp Budapest Sports Arena") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Hamilton_Hungary_2015_Qual.jpg/220px-Hamilton_Hungary_2015_Qual.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hamilton_Hungary_2015_Qual.jpg) [Hungarian Grand Prix](/wiki/Hungarian_Grand_Prix "Hungarian Grand Prix") on the [Hungaroring](/wiki/Hungaroring "Hungaroring")

Budapest hosted many global [sporting events](/wiki/Sport "Sport") in the past, among others the [1994 IAAF World Cross Country Championships](/wiki/1994_IAAF_World_Cross_Country_Championships "1994 IAAF World Cross Country Championships"), [1997 World Amateur Boxing Championships](/wiki/1997_World_Amateur_Boxing_Championships "1997 World Amateur Boxing Championships"), [2000 World Fencing Championships](/wiki/2000_World_Fencing_Championships "2000 World Fencing Championships"), [2001 World Allround Speed Skating Championships](/wiki/2001_World_Allround_Speed_Skating_Championships "2001 World Allround Speed Skating Championships"), [Bandy World Championship 2004](/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship_2004 "Bandy World Championship 2004"), [2008 World Interuniversity Games](/wiki/2008_World_Interuniversity_Games "2008 World Interuniversity Games"), [2008 World Modern Pentathlon Championships](/wiki/2008_World_Modern_Pentathlon_Championships "2008 World Modern Pentathlon Championships"), [2010 ITU World Championship Series](/wiki/2010_ITU_World_Championship_Series "2010 ITU World Championship Series"), 2011 [IIHF World Championship](/wiki/IIHF_World_Championship "IIHF World Championship"), [2012 European Speed Skating Championships](/wiki/2012_European_Speed_Skating_Championships "2012 European Speed Skating Championships"), [2013 World Fencing Championships](/wiki/2013_World_Fencing_Championships "2013 World Fencing Championships"), [2013 World Wrestling Championships](/wiki/2013_World_Wrestling_Championships "2013 World Wrestling Championships"), 2014 [World Masters Athletics Championships](/wiki/World_Masters_Athletics_Championships "World Masters Athletics Championships"), [2017 World Aquatics Championships](/wiki/2017_World_Aquatics_Championships "2017 World Aquatics Championships"), and [2017 World Judo Championships](/wiki/2017_World_Judo_Championships "2017 World Judo Championships"), only in the last two-decade. Besides these, Budapest was the home of many European-level tournaments, like [2006 European Aquatics Championships](/wiki/2006_European_Aquatics_Championships "2006 European Aquatics Championships"), [2010 European Aquatics Championships](/wiki/2010_European_Aquatics_Championships "2010 European Aquatics Championships"), [2010 UEFA Futsal Championship](/wiki/2010_UEFA_Futsal_Championship "2010 UEFA Futsal Championship"), [2013 European Judo Championships](/wiki/2013_European_Judo_Championships "2013 European Judo Championships"), [2013 European Karate Championships](/wiki/2013_European_Karate_Championships "2013 European Karate Championships") and will be the host of [2023 World Championships in Athletics](/wiki/2023_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2023 World Championships in Athletics") and 4 matches in the [UEFA Euro 2020](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020 "UEFA Euro 2020"), which was held in the 67,215-seat new [multi-purpose](/wiki/Multi-purpose_stadium "Multi-purpose stadium") [Puskás Ferenc Stadium](/wiki/New_Pusk%C3%A1s_Ferenc_Stadium "New Puskás Ferenc Stadium"), to mention a few.

In 2015, the Assembly of the [Hungarian Olympic Committee](/wiki/Hungarian_Olympic_Committee "Hungarian Olympic Committee") and the [Assembly of Budapest](/wiki/General_Assembly_of_Budapest "General Assembly of Budapest") decided to bid for the [2024 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics "2024 Summer Olympics"). Budapest has lost several bids to host the games, in 1916, 1920, 1936, 1944, and 1960 to [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), Antwerp, London, and Rome, respectively.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-235)^^[\[235\]](#cite_note-236)^ The [Hungarian Parliament](/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament "Hungarian Parliament") also voted to support the bid on 28 January 2016, later Budapest City Council approved list of venues and [Budapest became an official candidate for the 2024 Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Budapest_bid_for_the_2024_Summer_Olympics "Budapest bid for the 2024 Summer Olympics"). However, they withdrew their bid later on.{#cite_ref-236}

Numerous Olympic, World, and European Championship winners and medalists reside in the city, which follows from Hungary's 8th place among all the nations of the world in the [All-time Olympic Games medal table](/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table "All-time Olympic Games medal table").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Danube_Arena_in_2017_FINA_Budapest.jpg/220px-Danube_Arena_in_2017_FINA_Budapest.jpg)](/wiki/File:Danube_Arena_in_2017_FINA_Budapest.jpg) The [Danube Arena](/wiki/Danube_Arena "Danube Arena") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/National_Athletics_Centre_%28Budapest%2C_HUN%29_2023.jpg/220px-National_Athletics_Centre_%28Budapest%2C_HUN%29_2023.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Athletics_Centre_(Budapest,_HUN)_2023.jpg) The [National Athletics Centre](/wiki/National_Athletics_Centre_(Budapest) "National Athletics Centre (Budapest)")

Hungarians have always been avid sports people: during the history of the [Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games"), Hungarians have brought home 476 medals, of which 167 are gold. The top events in which Hungarians have excelled are fencing, swimming, water polo, canoeing, wrestling and track \& field sports. Beside classic sports, recreational modern sports such as bowling, pool billiard, darts, go-carting, wakeboarding and squash are very popular in Budapest, and extreme sports are also gaining ground. Furthermore, the [Budapest Marathon](/wiki/Budapest_Marathon "Budapest Marathon") and [Budapest Half Marathon](/wiki/Budapest_Half_Marathon "Budapest Half Marathon") also attract many people every year. The city's largest football stadium is named after [Ferenc Puskás](/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s "Ferenc Puskás"), recognised as the top scorer of the 20th century and for whom [FIFA Puskás Award](/wiki/FIFA_Pusk%C3%A1s_Award "FIFA Puskás Award") was named.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-237)^{#cite_ref-237}

One of Budapest's most popular sport is football and it has many [Hungarian League](/wiki/Hungarian_football_league_system "Hungarian football league system") football club, including in the top level [Nemzeti Bajnokság I](/wiki/Nemzeti_Bajnoks%C3%A1g_I "Nemzeti Bajnokság I") league, like [Ferencvárosi TC](/wiki/Ferencv%C3%A1rosi_TC "Ferencvárosi TC") (32 Hungarian League titles), [MTK Budapest FC](/wiki/MTK_Budapest_FC "MTK Budapest FC") (23 titles), [Újpest FC](/wiki/%C3%9Ajpest_FC "Újpest FC") (20 titles), [Budapest Honvéd FC](/wiki/Budapest_Honv%C3%A9d_FC "Budapest Honvéd FC") (14 titles), [Vasas SC](/wiki/Vasas_SC "Vasas SC") (6 titles), [Csepel SC](/wiki/Csepel_SC "Csepel SC") (4 titles), [Budapesti TC](/wiki/Budapesti_TC "Budapesti TC") (2 titles).

The [Hungarian Grand Prix](/wiki/Hungarian_Grand_Prix "Hungarian Grand Prix") in [Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One") has been held at the [Hungaroring](/wiki/Hungaroring "Hungaroring") just outside the city, a circuit which has [FIA](/wiki/FIA "FIA") Grade 1 license.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-238)^ Since 1986, the race has been a round of the FIA [Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One") World Championship. At the [2013 Hungarian Grand Prix](/wiki/2013_Hungarian_Grand_Prix "2013 Hungarian Grand Prix"), it was confirmed that Hungary will continue to host a Formula 1 race until 2021.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-239)^ The track was completely resurfaced for the first time in early 2016, and it was announced the Grand Prix's deal was extended for a further five years, until 2026.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-240)^{#cite_ref-240}

Budapest is home to two four-star UEFA stadiums: [Puskás Aréna](/wiki/Pusk%C3%A1s_Ar%C3%A9na "Puskás Aréna"), [Groupama Aréna](/wiki/Groupama_Ar%C3%A9na "Groupama Aréna"), and two three-star UEFA stadiums: [Hidegkuti Nándor Stadion](/wiki/Hidegkuti_N%C3%A1ndor_Stadion "Hidegkuti Nándor Stadion") and [Bozsik Aréna](/wiki/Bozsik_Ar%C3%A9na "Bozsik Aréna").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Budapest will be the home of the headquarters of the [World Aquatics](/wiki/World_Aquatics "World Aquatics") after moving from [Lausanne](/wiki/Lausanne "Lausanne") by the [2027 World Aquatics Championships](/w/index.php?title=2027_World_Aquatics_Championships&action=edit&redlink=1 "2027 World Aquatics Championships (page does not exist)").^[\[240\]](#cite_note-241)^{#cite_ref-241}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Education")\]  
See also: [Education in Hungary](/wiki/Education_in_Hungary "Education in Hungary")

Budapest is home to over 35 higher education institutions, many of which are universities. Under the [Bologna Process](/wiki/Bologna_Process "Bologna Process"), many offered qualifications are recognised in countries across Europe. Medicine, dentistry, pharmaceuticals, veterinary programs, and engineering are among the most popular fields for foreigners to undertake in Budapest. Most universities in Budapest offer courses in English, as well as in other languages like German, French, and Dutch, aimed specifically at foreigners. Many students from other European countries spend one or two semesters in Budapest through the [Erasmus Programme](/wiki/Erasmus_Programme "Erasmus Programme").^[\[241\]](#cite_note-242)^{#cite_ref-242}

International relations {#International_relations}
--------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Budapest&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: International relations")\]

Budapest has quite a few [sister cities](/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities "Twin towns and sister cities") and many partner cities around the world.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-Budapest_twinnings-243)^ Like Budapest, many of them are the most influential and largest cities of their country and region, most of them are the primate city and political, economical, cultural capital of their country. The Mayor of Budapest says the aim of improving sister city relationships is to allow and encourage a mutual exchange of information and experiences, as well as co-operation, in the areas of city management, education, culture, tourism, media and communication, trade and business development.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-244)^^\[*[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^{#cite_ref-244}  

### Historic sister cities {#Historic_sister_cities}
